This section shall not apply to an icebox, refrigerator, or other airtight or semi-airtight container located in that part of a building occupied by a dealer, warehouseman, or repairman. Penalty, see  94.99. (R.C. 3767.29) 
(Ord. 728-1973; Ord. 821-1972) 
94.14.1 - Outdoor use of refrigerators and appliances. 
    No owner, occupant, or person in charge of any premises shall store, use or knowingly permit to remain on premises under his control, in any outdoor area susceptible to moisture from inclement weather, including rain, snow or hail, any electrical appliance, including but not limited to any icebox, refrigerator, washer, dryer or stove, that is either operating or connected to a source of electricity. This section shall not apply to any electrical appliance specifically designed and intended for outdoor use. 
(Ord. 532-2000) 
94.15 - Storage of junk motor vehicles. 
A.  Definition. 
1.  " Junk motor vehicle ." Any motor vehicle which meets any three of the following requirements: 
a.  Is three years old or older; 
b.  Is extensively damaged, such damage, including, but not limited to, any of the following: missing wheels, tires, motors or transmission; 
c.  Does not comply with all safety laws and equipment provisions for motor vehicles as found in Chapter 74; 
d.  Has a fair market value of one thousand five hundred dollars or less; 
e.  Is not running and not operable ("operable" meaning able to be started and driven under its own power). 
2.  A junk motor vehicle left in the open is declared a nuisance and shall be abated in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
3.  " Motor vehicle ." Shall be defined as in  70.01 of this code. 
B.  Prohibitions. 
1.  No person shall willfully permit a junk motor vehicle to remain in the open on private property which the person owns, occupies or controls after receipt of an order to remove the junk motor vehicle. The order shall state that a hearing appealing the order to remove the junk motor vehicle may be had, shall describe the vehicle to be removed, and shall be served by an Inspector of the Department of Neighborhood Assistance by personal service to both an occupant of the property and the owner of the property, or if personal service is not accomplished, then by posting in a conspicuous location at the property affected and mailing, by regular mail, to the address of the affected property if there is a dwelling thereon and to the property owner at the location to which the Auditor mails the tax bill for the property affected. 
2.  If any recipient of an order to remove a junk motor vehicle or an unlicensed or inoperable vehicle under  94.16 shall fail to appeal the same in writing within seven days after its posting, personal service or mailing, whichever occurs first, to the Director of Neighborhood Assistance, it shall be conclusively presumed to establish the junk, unlicensed or inoperable motor vehicle as a nuisance and the motor vehicle shall be removed by the Police Division immediately. The fact that a junk motor vehicle or an unlicensed or inoperable vehicle under  94.16 is left on private property without the filing of an appeal by the recipient of an order to remove a junk, unlicensed or inoperable motor vehicle is prima facie evidence of willful failure to comply with the order. If, following appeal under  94.31 of this chapter, the Director affirms the order to remove a junk, unlicensed or inoperable motor vehicle, the Director shall order the removal of the particular vehicle by the Police Division. 
3.  No person shall leave a junk motor vehicle for any period of time on private property to which such person does not have the right of possession without the authorization of the person having the right of possession of such property. 
C.  Storage and Disposal of Junk Motor Vehicles. 
1.  After a motor vehicle has been determined to be a junk motor vehicle, as provided herein, the Police Division shall immediately cause the junk motor vehicle to be removed from the property where the junk motor vehicle is located by a salvage service duly designated by the Director of Neighborhood Assistance and stored in a designated facility. 
2.  Any junk motor vehicle which has been removed and stored pursuant to this section shall be disposed of in accordance with the following procedures: 
    The Chief of Police immediately shall cause a search to be made of the records of the Bureau of Motor Vehicles to ascertain the owner and any lienholder of the motor vehicle ordered into storage by the Chief of Police. If known, the Chief shall send or cause to be sent notice to the owner or lienholder at the owner's or lienholder's last known address by certified mail with return receipt requested, that the motor vehicle has been declared a nuisance and will be disposed of if not claimed within ten days of the date of mailing of the notice. The owner or lienholder of the motor vehicle may reclaim it upon payment of any expenses or charges incurred in its removal and storage, and presentation of proof of ownership, which may be evidenced by a certificate of title to the motor vehicle. If the owner or lienholder of the motor vehicle reclaims it after a search of the records of the Bureau has been conducted and after notice has been sent to the owner or lienholder as described in this section, and the search was conducted by the designated salvage service, and the notice was sent to the motor vehicle owner by the designated salvage service, the owner or lienholder shall pay to the designated salvage service a processing fee of twenty-five dollars, in addition to any expenses or charges incurred in the removal and storage of the vehicle. If the owner or lienholder makes no claim to the motor vehicle within ten days of the date of mailing of the notice: (a) the vehicle shall be disposed of by a motor vehicle salvage service or other facility as provided in  4513.62 of the Revised Code, (b) the Chief of Police shall execute in triplicate an affidavit, as prescribed by the Registrar of Motor Vehicles, describing the motor vehicle and the manner in which it will be disposed of, and that all requirements of this section have been complied with. The Chief of Police shall retain the original of the affidavit for the Chief's records, and shall furnish two copies to the motor vehicle salvage service or other facility. Upon presentation of a copy of the affidavit by the motor vehicle salvage service, the Clerk of Courts shall issue to such owner a salvage certificate of title, free and clear of all liens and encumbrances. 
    Whenever a motor vehicle salvage service or other facility receives an affidavit for the disposal of a motor vehicle as provided in this section, the designated salvage service or facility shall not be required to obtain an Ohio certificate of title to the motor vehicle in the salvage service's or facility's own name if the vehicle is dismantled or destroyed and both copies of the affidavit are delivered to the Clerk of Courts. 
D.  Whoever fails to remove a junk motor vehicle left in the open, after receipt of a proper order to remove the same, is guilty of a third degree misdemeanor. Each junk motor vehicle left in the open in violation of subsection B of this section shall constitute a separate offense. Every twenty days that this section is violated shall constitute a separate offense. 
E.  Expenses as a Lien. In addition to the penalty provided in subsection D of this section, all expenses, administrative charges and/or fines shall be assessed pursuant to  94.32. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 222-2008 1: Ord. 148-2005: Ord. 634-2004; Ord. 376-2002; Ord. 373-1996; Ord. 754-2008; Ord. 772-1986; Ord. 439-1981; Ord. 604-1979) 
(Ord. 13-2010; Ord. 2010-2012) 
94.16 - Storage of unlicensed vehicles. 
    No person shall park or store, or permit to be parked or stored, for a period of more than ten days, any unlicensed motor vehicle or any vehicle not in operating condition except in an enclosed building or garage or as otherwise permitted by law. In addition to the penalty provided in  94.99(G) and 94.32, a motor vehicle parked or stored in violation of this section after ten days' notice of such violation, served in the manner stated in  94.15(B)(1) and the opportunity for appeal provided by  94.15(B)(2), by the Police Division or the Director of Neighborhood Assistance or their designees, may be removed to a motor vehicle pound or other place of storage by any Police Officer, at his discretion, and shall not be released except on payment of towing and storage charges. Motor vehicles so removed may be disposed of according to the provisions of R.C.  4513.61, et seq. 
(Ord. 222-2008 1: Ord. 722-1986; Ord. 604-1979; Ord. 916-1965) 
(Ord. 13-2010; Ord. 210-2012) 
94.16.1 - Historical motor vehicles. 
    Any person claiming Historical Motor Vehicle status for any motor vehicle in defense of a violation of Section 94.15 or 94.16 of this code must provide proof that said vehicle is registered as an Historical Motor Vehicle with the Ohio Bureau of Motor Vehicles, has been inspected, and is currently safe to operate on the highways of the state. 
(Ord. 713-1992) 
94.17 - Discharge of offensive substances. 
    No owner, manager, or person in charge of any cattle pen, stable, tannery, brewery, distillery, factory, shop, store, packing house, or other premises shall discharge therefrom or permit to be discharged therefrom, any foul, nauseous, or offensive liquids or substances into or onto any adjacent building or grounds, or on any street, alley, or public ground, or into any canal, pond, lake, stream of water, or into the City's separate storm sewer system. Penalty, see  94.99. (R.C. 3701.82) 
(Ord. 443-1994) 
94.18 - Keeping putrid substances. 
    No soapmaker, gluemaker, butcher, dealer in hides, skins, groceries, or provisions, nor any other person, shall keep or use, or cause to be kept or used, any stale, putrid, or stinking fat, grease, meat, hides, or skins or any putrid vegetable or animal substance. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.19 - Offensive or nauseous conditions. 
    No owner, occupant, or person in charge of any building, room, or premises, including the curtilage or surrounding area thereof, shall cause or permit the same, or any area, part thereof or appurtenant thereto, to become foul, nauseous, or offensive or neglect or fail to abate the foul, offensive, or nauseous condition by cleaning, disinfecting or other proper action, as may be ordered by the Director of Neighborhood Assistance, within forty-eight hours after service of the notice and order. The notice and order shall be served on the person personally, or by certified mail and regular mail to the person's residence, regular place of business or last known address. If the certified or regular mail is returned undelivered, a copy shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or on the person's residence, regular place of business, last known address, or the property affected. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 532-2000) 
(Ord. 13-2010; Ord. 210-2012) 
94.19.1 - Outdoor use of furniture susceptible to weather and rodents. 
A.  No owner, occupant or person in charge of any building, room or premises shall store, use or permit to remain on premises under his control, in any outdoor area susceptible to moisture from inclement weather, including rain, snow or hail, or infestation by insect, rodent or other pest, any furniture designed for indoor use, including but not limited to cushions, pillows, mattresses, couches and chairs. This subsection shall not apply to furniture specifically designed and intended for outdoor use and exposure to moisture from inclement weather or furniture designed and intended for indoor use that, due to the materials it is composed of, is not susceptible to damage due to moisture from inclement weather or infestation, including plastic, rubber, vinyl, wood, wicker or metal. 
B.  No owner, occupant or person in charge of any building, room or premises shall store, use or permit to remain on premises under his control, in any outdoor area, furniture which was originally designed for outdoor use, which is now dilapidated or deteriorated. 
C.  This section shall not apply to otherwise prohibited furniture properly deposited on or near the curb for litter collection pursuant to Chapter 52. 
(Ord. 532-2000) 
94.19.2 - Maintaining large storage or waste containers in residence districts. 
A.  As used in this section, a "large storage or waste container" is a vessel of more than ninety-six (96) gallons designed or used to store materials for re-use or disposal at a later time and includes, but is not limited to, PODS, (personal on-demand storage units), storage cubes, cargo containers, shipping containers, roll-off containers, bagsters, and dumpsters. 
B.  As used in this section a "residence district" is the territory fronting on a street or highway, where, for a distance of three hundred feet or more, the frontage is improved with residences or residences and buildings in use for business. 
C.  1.  No person shall maintain a large storage or waste container in a residence district for more than thirty (30) consecutive days. 
2.  No person shall maintain a large storage or waste container in a residence use district for more than ninety (90) days during any calendar year. 
3.  No person shall maintain a large storage or waste container in a condition that is unsafe, unsanitary or otherwise constitutes a nuisance, and shall maintain the container so as not to allow access by children or trespassers, through the use of latches, locks, pins, and similar devices, whenever possible. 
4.  No person shall maintain more than one large storage or waste container on the same parcel simultaneously in a residence district. 
5.  No person shall maintain a large storage or waste container on a City street, a City sidewalk, or City right-of-way. 
D.  This section shall not be interpreted or enforced to prohibit the use of large waste containers serving multi-unit dwellings or commercial buildings on a permanent basis, sheds or similar storage buildings, or compost pile enclosures, when properly maintained, constructed and placed pursuant to applicable law. 
(Ord. 145-2016) 
94.20 - Graffiti. 
A.  Notice to Remove. 
1.  For the purpose of this section, "graffiti" shall mean a crude drawing or inscription scratched or painted on a wall or other surface, usually so as to be seen by the public. 
2.  Whenever the Director of Neighborhood Assistance becomes aware of the existence of graffiti on any structure or improvement within the city, he shall give, or cause to be given, written notice of such violation to the property owner and order the property owner to remove the graffiti. 
3.  Such written notice and order and any appeal therefrom shall be governed by the procedure set forth in  94.31. 
B.  Removal of Condition by City. 
1.  If an owner fails to remove the graffiti within the time specified on the notice and order, the Director of Neighborhood Assistance shall remove or cause to be removed the graffiti and may employ the necessary labor to perform such work or cause it to be done by the appropriate City division. 
2.  All expenses, administrative charges, and/or fines incurred by the removal of the graffiti shall be assessed pursuant to  94.32. 
3.  If after thirty days such amount remains unpaid, the Director of Finance shall certify the total amount of the expenses, the name of the owner of the land and a sufficient description of the premises to the County Auditor, to be entered on the tax duplicate, to be a lien on the land from the date of entry and to be collected as other taxes and assessments and returned to the City pursuant to R.C.  731.54. This remedy shall be in addition to the penalty provided in  94.99. 
4.  The City may sue in any court of competent jurisdiction to recover the costs of removal of such graffiti, including the administrative charge as set forth in subsection (B)(2) of this section. 
C.  Right of Entry. No person shall refuse to allow access to any premises for the purpose of removing graffiti or to interfere with the removal of such graffiti. 
(Ord. 222-2008 1: Ord. 634-2004; Ord. 343-1991; Ord. 845-1990) 
(Ord. 13-2010; Ord. 210-2012) 
94.21 - Deposit of dead animals or wastes. 
    No person shall place the carcass of any animal or fowl, or any part thereof, or any decayed or putrid animal or vegetable matter, or any slops, waste water, or filth, on any street, alley, or public or private ground, or into any cistern, well, stream, canal, lake, reservoir, pond, or other body of water within the City, or into the City's separate storm sewer system. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 443-1994) 
94.22 - Deposit of certain substances in sewers. 
A.  No person shall place, throw, discharge or deposit any butcher's offal or garbage, dead animals, gaseous liquid, or solid matter or material, (other than allowable sanitary sewage into the sewage system) or obstructions of any kind, into any catch basin, sewer, drain, or into the sewage system or the separate storm sewer system within the City of Akron. No oil, gasoline, gas, residuum of gas of calcium carbide, tar, steam from a steam boiler or engine or from any building in which steam is either generated or used, water above 110F., manufacturing waste or greasy waste from kitchens, laundries, or other sources, shall be placed in or discharged into any public sewer, drain, or catch basin, when of such nature or in such quantities as may tend to clog, block, obstruct, or injure any public sewer, drain, or catch basin or make them unsafe for the purpose of repair or maintenance, or which may interfere with the effective operation of any sewage treatment plants. 
B.  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any such matter or material into any public sewer, drain, or catch basin, or injure, break, remove, or cause any portion of any catch basin, manhole, or other part of a sewer or appurtenance to be injured, broken, or removed, or obstruct in any manner the inlet or outlet of any public sewer or drain. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 443-1994) 
94.23 - Noxious odors-Filthy accumulations-Polluting watercourses. 
A.  No person shall erect, continue, use, or maintain a dwelling, building, structure, or place for a residence or for the exercise of a trade, employment, or business, or for the keeping or feeding of an animal which, by occasioning noxious exhalations or noisome or offensive smells, becomes injurious to the health, comfort, or property of individuals or of the public. 
B.  No person shall cause or allow offal, filth, or noisome substances to be collected or remain in any place to the damage or prejudice of others or of the public. 
C.  No person shall unlawfully obstruct or impede the passage of a navigable river, harbor, or collection of water, or corrupt or render unwholesome or impure, a watercourse or stream, or water, or unlawfully divert such watercourse from its natural course or state to the injury or prejudice of others. (R.C.  3767.13) 
94.24 - Burning rubber products. 
A.  For the purpose of this section, "rubber" and "rubber products" shall mean any substance of which rubber composes a material or substantial part, whether the same is fabricated or compounded. 
B.  No person shall burn rubber or other substances in the City which, during the process of combustion, shall emit unhealthful or otherwise offensive smoke or odors. However, this section shall not apply to the burning of such substances in incinerators or furnaces constructed in conformity with good engineering practice, as approved by the Superintendent of Building Inspection and Regulation. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.25 - Burning garbage. 
    No person shall burn garbage. However, this section shall not apply to the burning of garbage in incinerators that are constructed in conformity with good engineering practice, as approved by the Superintendent of Building Inspection and Regulation, and that are used in burning only the garbage accumulated at the premises wherein such incinerator is situated. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 35-1960) 
94.26 - Spitting. 
    No person shall spit or expectorate on any sidewalk or other public walk, or on the floor of any public building or on the floor of any public vehicle. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.27 - Burying corpses outside of cemetery. 
    No person shall bury or entomb the body of any deceased person in or on any ground within the City that is not owned or used for the purpose of a cemetery. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.28 - Asphalt mixing plants. 
    No person shall operate an asphalt mixing plant or any other similar plant in the City, if the sand, dust, or lime rock dust from the blower of such plant is forced into the open air to the detriment or annoyance of the people residing in the vicinity of such plant. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.29 - Noxious weeds. 
A.  No person who is the owner or in charge of land within the City shall permit to grow thereon any ragweed, field daisies, goldenrod, burdock, yellowdock, dandelions, thistles, jimpson weeds, milkweeds, polygonum, mullein, poison ivy, poison oak, or other weeds or grasses of rank growth, exceeding eight inches in height. Inspection shall occur during the growing season, beginning not later than April 1st of each year, and concluding no earlier than the first killing frost as recorded by the Department of Commerce, National Weather Service Office of local jurisdiction. 
B.  On information that noxious weeds, including ragweed, field daisies, dandelions, goldenrod, burdock, yellow dock, polygonum, thistles, or any other weeds or grasses or growth which gives off offensive or noxious odors, or from which any injurious, offensive, or annoying pollen, dust, down, seed, or particles may be carried, or which may conceal filthy deposits, are growing on land within the City, the Director of Neighborhood Assistance will cause the notice to be posted in a conspicuous place on the subject property and served by personal service to both an occupant of the property and the owner of the property, or if personal service is not accomplished, then by mailing, by regular mail, to the address of the subject property if there is a dwelling thereon, and to the property owner at the location to which the auditor mails the tax bill for the subject property notifying the owner, lessee, agent, tenant, or other person having charge of the subject property that such weeds or other growth must be cut or destroyed within five days after posting of such notice. This notice shall contain the date of posting and the location of the property. Such weeds or other growth must be cut or destroyed within five days after personal service, mailing or posting of such notice, whichever occurs first. Such written notice and order and any appeal therefrom shall be governed by  94.31. 
C.  If the owner or other person in charge of the subject property fails to comply within seven days from the posting of the notice, the Director of Neighborhood Assistance shall cause the noxious weeds to be cut and destroyed and may employ the necessary labor to perform such work or cause it to be done by the appropriate City division. 
D.  All expenses, administrative charges, and/or fines resulting from the City cutting and destroying such noxious weeds or grasses shall be assessed pursuant to  94.32. 
E.  One notice to cut or destroy noxious weeds shall be deemed notice for all subsequent violations at the subject property, subject to the following conditions: 
1.  Upon service of a notice to cut or remove noxious weeds or growth pursuant to subsection (B) of this section, the Director of Neighborhood Assistance shall include the subject property upon a master mowing list of properties unless and until: 
(a)  The owner or other person responsible for the subject property successfully appeals the notice pursuant to  94.31 such that the notice is dismissed; or 
(b)  The Director of Neighborhood Assistance observes that the owner or other person responsible for the subject property maintains the subject property in compliance with subsection (A) of this section for a period of one hundred twenty (120) consecutive days during a growing season. 
F.  Upon the Director of Neighborhood Assistance observing that a property listed upon the master mowing list has satisfied subsection (e) of this section, he shall remove the subject property from the master mowing list, record that the notice has been complied, and otherwise close the matter with written notice to the owner or other person responsible for the subject property that such has occurred by regular mail. 
G.  The Director of Neighborhood Assistance shall maintain the master mowing list as a public record, updated as necessary and provided upon request, and may provide electronic access by means of a link to the website maintained by the City. 
(Ord. 222-2008 1: Ord. 634-2004; Ord. 93-1989; Ord. 117-1986; Ord. 479-1985; Ord. 186-1985; Ord. 226-1981; Ord. 919-1976) 
(Ord. 13-2010; Ord. 87-2011; Ord. 210-2012; Ord. 396-2016) 
94.30 - Inspection of premises for nuisances. 
A.  It shall be the duty of the Department of Neighborhood Assistance, acting through its properly authorized employees, when it is deemed necessary in order to secure or preserve the public health, safety, and welfare to enter onto private land or other property of any person within the City, on the premises or into the house, factory, workshop, or other place of any person within the City to ascertain any nuisance that may exist there under Article 2 of this chapter. 
B.  It shall be the duty of the Department of Public Health through its properly authorized employees, when it is deemed necessary in order to preserve the public health and safety, to enter onto private land or other property of any person within the City to ascertain all nuisances that may exist under Article 1, 3, 4 and 5 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 222-2008 1: Ord. 987-1990) 
(Ord. 13-2010; Ord. 210-2012) 
94.31 - Ordering improper conditions to be remedied-Notice and appeal. 
A.  When the Department of Public Health, acting through its properly authorized employees, after inspection of premises under the provisions of  94.30 of this chapter, is satisfied that the premises contains conditions that constitute a nuisance or a health hazard, the Department of Health shall serve a written notice in the manner described herein, to correct or remove the nuisance or objection therein named, or otherwise correct the condition. When the Department of Neighborhood Assistance, acting through its properly authorized employees, after inspection of a premises under the provisions of  94.30 of this chapter, is satisfied that the premises are maintained in violation of any provision or provisions of Article 2 of this chapter, the Department shall serve a written notice to the owner, agent, lessee, occupant, tenant, or other person in charge of the premises to correct or remove the violating condition therein named. The notice and order shall be served by personal service to both an occupant of the property and the owner of the property, or if personal service is not accomplished, then by posting in a conspicuous location at the property affected and mailing, by regular mail, to the address of the affected property if there is a dwelling thereon and to the property owner at the location to which the auditor mails the tax bill for the property affected. 
B.  Appeal of Notice and Order. Any person affected by any notice and order to remedy a nuisance condition may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the Director of Neighborhood Assistance or his designee. The person shall file, in the office of the Director of Neighborhood Assistance, a written request for the hearing and shall set forth the name, address, and phone number of the appellant and a brief statement of the grounds for the hearing and appeal from the order to remedy a nuisance condition. Requests must be filed within seven days after the notice and order is personally served, mailed or posted, whichever occurs first and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable deposit of fifteen dollars. 
1.  On receipt of the request for a hearing, the Director of Neighborhood Assistance or his designee shall set a time and place for a hearing. Written notice of the hearing shall be sent by regular mail to the address provided by appellant in the request for hearing. The hearing shall be held within a reasonable time after a request has been filed. 
2.  At the hearing, the appellant shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show cause why the notice and order should be modified or dismissed. The failure of the appellant or his representative to appear and present his position at the hearing shall be grounds for dismissal of the request. 
3.  Upon consideration of the evidence presented at the hearing, the Director of Neighborhood Assistance or his designee may affirm, disaffirm, modify, or dismiss the notice and order to remedy a nuisance condition. The appellant shall be notified forthwith in writing of the decision. 
4.  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the Director of Neighborhood Assistance may seek relief therefrom pursuant to R.C. Chapter 2506. 
C.  Whenever the Director of Neighborhood Assistance finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, safety or welfare, he may, without notice or hearing, issue an order stating the existence of such an emergency and requiring that such action be taken as he deems necessary to meet the emergency. The order shall be effective immediately. Any person to whom the order is directed shall comply therewith immediately, but, on petition to the Director of Neighborhood Assistance, shall be afforded a hearing as soon as possible. After the hearing, depending on his finding as to whether or not the emergency condition has been abated, the Director of Neighborhood Assistance shall continue the order in effect or modify or revoke it. 
(Ord. 222-2008 1: Ord. 597-2006: Ord. 532-2000) 
(Ord. 13-2010; Ord. 210-2012) 
94.32 - Noncompliance-Remedy of city. 
A.  If any owner, agent, occupant, lessee, tenant or other person in charge of the premises referred to in  94.31 of this chapter neglects or refuses to obey such notice, the Director of Neighborhood Assistance or a properly authorized employee is authorized to put the premises in proper order at the expense of such owner, occupant, agent, lessee, tenant or other person having charge thereof. 
B.  All expenses so incurred to remedy the nuisance condition by the Director of Neighborhood Assistance together with an administrative charge and/or fine, as described hereafter, shall be reported to the Director of Finance, who shall mail a statement thereof to the owner of the property, if his address is known. If after thirty days, the amount remains unpaid, the Director of Finance shall certify the total amount of the expense, the name of the owner of the land, and a sufficient description of the premises, to the Auditor of Summit County, to be entered upon the tax duplicate, to be a lien on the land from the date of entry, to be collected as other taxes and assessments and returned to the City, pursuant to R.C.  731.54. 
C.  In addition to the actual expenses described above, the owner of the premises must pay an administrative charge. For the first and second times in a calendar year that the City abates a nuisance under this chapter, maintains a sidewalk or other property under Chapter 98, maintains a tree under Chapter 101, and/or removes litter under Chapter 95 on the premises, the administrative charge each time will be two hundred dollars. Should the City be required to abate additional nuisances, maintain sidewalks or other property, maintain a tree, or remove additional litter on those premises a third or subsequent time within that calendar year, in addition to the expenses incurred and the administrative penalty described above, a fine of two hundred fifty dollars will be charged to the owner. The remedy provided for herein shall be in addition to the penalties provided in  94.99 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 222-2008 1: Ord. 597-2006) 
(Ord. 210-2012; Ord. 353-2016) 
94.33 - Placing harmful substance in food or confection. 
    No person shall do either of the following, knowing or having reasonable cause to believe that any person may suffer physical harm or be seriously inconvenienced or annoyed thereby: 
A.  Place a pin, needle, razor blade, glass, laxative, drug of abuse, or other harmful or hazardous object or substance in any food or confection; 
B.  Furnish to any person any food or confection which has been adulterated in violation of subsection A of this section. Penalty, see  94.99. (R.C.  3716.11, 3716.99(C)) 
(Ord. 728-1973) 
94.34 - Compost piles. 
A.  Compliance Required. No property owner or person lawfully in charge of the premises shall maintain or cause to be maintained a compost pile within the City limits, except when the compost pile complies with the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  Definition. As used in this chapter, "compost pile" means any outdoor pile of organic waste matter permitted to decompose. 
C.  Ingredients. A compost pile may consist of combinations of leaves, grass clippings, herbivore animal manure, garden plants and vegetable trimmings, fruit and vegetable material, nitrogenous based chemicals or fertilizers, and water. There shall not be permitted the addition of any animal manure, fruit or vegetable substances other than those specified herein, cooked kitchen waste, grease, meat, bones, or fats, to any compost pile in the City. 
D.  Formation. A compost pile shall be started at ground level and shall be layered in alternate layers of six to twelve inches of leaves, grass clippings, or plant residues, a second layer of two to three inches of vegetable materials or herbivore manure, a third layer of nitrogen-based chemicals or fertilizers, and a fourth layer of one to two inches of rich topsoil, with the repetition of the layers until the pile has reached five feet above ground level. The compost pile is to be covered with soil at the end of the day. No compost pile in the City shall exceed five feet in height above ground level. 
E.  Enclosure. All compost piles shall be within an enclosure to conceal visibility. The compost pile shall be constructed with suitable screens, materials or enclosures to prevent rodents and other vectors from entering or exiting the enclosure. 
F.  Nauseous Odors. Compost piles shall be operated in a manner so as to not cause offensive or nauseous odors. 
G.  Rodent and Insect Control. The property owner or person lawfully in charge of a premises shall have the sole responsibility for the control and elimination of rodents and insects which might be attracted to the area. 
H.  Location. Any compost pile must not be visible from any street or sidewalk and shall be no less than ten feet from any building line or fifteen feet from an inhabited dwelling. 
I.  Removal. The property owner, or person lawfully in possession of property, upon which a compost pile in violation of this chapter is located, shall completely remove the compost pile within seven days after receipt of written notice from the City. Failure to remove a compost pile pursuant to a notice given in this section shall be deemed a violation of this section. The notice and order shall be served on the person personally, or by certified mail and regular mail to the person's residence, regular place of business or last known address. If the certified or regular mail is returned undelivered, a copy shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or on the person's residence, regular place of business, last known address, or the property affected. 
J.  Noncompliance-Remedy of City. 
1.  If the property owner or other person lawfully in charge of the premises upon which the compost pile is located neglects or refuses to obey the notice, the Director of Neighborhood Assistance or a properly authorized employee or agent of the Department of Neighborhood Assistance, is authorized to remove the compost pile at the expense of the owner or other person having charge thereof. 
2.  All expenses incurred by removing and destroying the compost pile, together with an administrative charge of seventy-five dollars or ten percent of all expenses incurred by removing and destroying the compost pile, whichever is greater, for each notice processed, shall be reported to the Director of Finance, who shall mail a statement of the amount thereof to the owner or other person in charge of the premises. If, after thirty days, the amount remains unpaid, the Director of Finance shall certify the total amount of the expenses, the name of the owner of the land and a sufficient description of the premises to the County Auditor, to be entered on the tax duplicate, to be a lien on the premises from the date of entry and to be collected as other taxes and assessments and returned to the City, pursuant to R.C.  731.54. This remedy shall be in addition to the penalty provided in  94.99. 
(Ord. 532-2000; Ord. 799-1986) 
(Ord. 13-2010; Ord. 210-2012) 
94.35 - Clandestine drug labs. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  "Chemical dumpsite" means any place or area where chemicals or other waste materials used, intended to be used, or produced in a clandestine drug lab have been located. 
2.  "Clandestine drug lab" means a location used for the unlawful manufacture or attempt to manufacture controlled substances. 
3.  "Clandestine drug lab site" means any place or area where law enforcement has determined that conditions associated with the operation of a clandestine drug lab exist. A clandestine drug lab site may include residential, commercial, industrial or institutional structures, accessory buildings, accessory structures, motor vehicles, a chemical dumpsite or any land. 
4.  "Controlled substance" means a drug, compound, mixture, preparation, or substance included in schedules I through V of Ohio Revised Code  3719.41 or as amended from time to time. The term does not include distilled spirits, wine, malt beverages, intoxicating liquors or tobacco. 
5.  "Expense" means any expense incurred due to the use of employees, materials, and/or equipment of the City or its agent to investigate, mitigate, minimize, remove or abate any hazardous condition. 
6.  "Household hazardous wastes" means waste generated from a clandestine drug lab. Such wastes shall be treated, stored, transported or disposed of in a manner consistent with all federal, state and local regulations. 
7.  "Manufacture" means the production, cultivation, quality control, and standardization, by mechanical, physical, chemical or pharmaceutical means, packing, repacking, tableting, encapsulating, labeling, relabeling, filling, or by other process, of controlled substances. This does not include manufacturing which occurs in a pharmacy or a licensed pharmaceutical manufacturing facility. 
8.  "Owner" means any person, firm or corporation who alone or jointly or severally with others has legal title to any land, buildings, or structures associated with a clandestine drug lab site or chemical dumpsite, with or without accompanying actual possession thereof. Owner also includes vendor or vendee under a land contract, whether recorded or not, or the executor, executrix, administrator, administratrix, trustee, or guardian of the estate of either the person with legal title or the land contract vendor or vendee. 
B.  Where an Akron Police Officer determines that an emergency condition caused by hazardous conditions associated with a clandestine drug lab site or chemical dumpsite exists, the City may dismantle and dispose of drug processing apparatus and/or chemicals. Upon identification of such emergency condition, an Akron Police Officer shall serve written notice to the owner, agent, lessee, occupant, tenant or other person in charge of the premises that an emergency condition exists and ordering that the cost of abating the emergency condition be paid to the City. The notice and order shall be served by personal service to both an occupant of the property and the owner of the property, or if personal service is not accomplished, then by posting in a conspicuous location at the property affected and mailing, by regular mail, to the address of the affected property if there is a dwelling thereon and to the property owner at the location to which the auditor mails the tax bill for the property affected. 
C.  Any person affected by any notice and order to pay the cost of abating an emergency condition may request and shall be granted a hearing on the matter before the Chief of Police or his designee. The person shall file, in the office of the Chief of Police, a written request for hearing and shall set forth the name, address and phone number of the appellant and a brief statement of the grounds for the hearing and appeal from the notice and order to pay the cost of abating the emergency condition. Requests must be filed within seven days after the notice and order is personally served, mailed or posted, whichever occurs first and shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable deposit of fifteen dollars. 
1.  On receipt of the request for hearing, the Chief of Police or his designee shall set a time and place for a hearing. Written notice of the hearing shall be sent by regular mail to the address provided by appellant in the request for hearing. The hearing shall be held within a reasonable time after a request has been filed. 
2.  At the hearing, the appellant shall be given an opportunity to be heard and to show cause why the notice and order should be modified or dismissed. The failure of the appellant or his representative to appear and present his position at the hearing shall be grounds for dismissal of the request. 
3.  Upon consideration of the evidence presented at the hearing, the Chief of Police or his designee may affirm, disaffirm, modify or dismiss the notice and order. The appellant shall be notified forthwith in writing of the decision. 
4.  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the Chief of Police or his designee may seek relief pursuant to R.C. Chapter 2506. 
D.  All expenses incurred to remedy the emergency condition by the City of Akron together with an administrative charge and/or fine, as described below, shall be reported to the Director of Finance, who shall mail a statement thereof to the owner of the property, if his address is known. Expenses associated with a first occurrence only shall not exceed $1,200.00 which includes the administrative charges set forth below. If after thirty days, the amount remains unpaid, the Director of Finance shall certify the total amount of the expense, the name of the owner of the land, and a sufficient description of the premises, to the Auditor of Summit County, to be entered upon the tax duplicate, to be a lien on the land from the date of entry, to be collected as other taxes and assessments and returned to the City, pursuant to R.C.  731.54. 
E.  In addition to the actual expenses described above, the owner of the premises must pay an administrative charge. For the first and second times in a calendar year that the City abates emergency conditions under this section, the administrative charge each time will be two hundred dollars. Should the City be required to abate an emergency condition or any other condition listed in section 94.32(C), a third or subsequent time within that calendar year, in addition to the expenses incurred and the administrative penalty described above, a fine of two hundred fifty dollars will be charged to the owner. The remedy provided for herein shall be in addition to the penalties provided in  94.99 of this chapter. 
F.  Fifty dollars of the amount collected for each emergency condition abated under this section shall be used for drug awareness education within the City. 
(Ord. 117-2012) 
Article 3. - Privies and Septic Tanks 

94.50 - Sewage disposal for buildings required. 
    No person shall occupy or permit to be occupied, any building used for the purpose of human habitation or business until proper provisions for sewage disposal have been installed and approved by the Director of Health. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.51 - Control of cesspools-Vaults. 
    All cesspools, vaults, and other like receptacles for house drainage, in areas where no proper sewerage system is provided, shall be under the control of the Director of Public Health and shall be constructed, ventilated, and emptied as he directs. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.52 - Privies and water closets-Nuisance conditions. 
A.  Every building within the City shall be furnished with water closets, privies or privy vaults of sufficient number and size to accommodate all persons who work in or inhabit the buildings or use the water closets, privies or privy vaults. Each privy erected or built within the City, except those constructed with sewer connections so as to be cleaned by flowing water, shall have under the same a vault at least five feet deep and watertight, constructed in accordance with plans recommended by the Director of Health. The owner, agent, occupant or other person having control of the premises on which any such water closet, privy, or privy vault is situated, shall keep the water closet, privy or privy vault in good and constant repair and condition. 
B.  No owner, occupant or person having charge of premises on which a water closet, privy, privy vault or other place or receptacle for the deposit of excreta or other waste is situated, shall allow the same to become foul, nauseous or offensive, or neglect or fail to abate the foul, nauseous or offensive condition by cleaning, disinfecting or other proper action, as may be ordered by the Director of Health, within forty-eight hours after service of the notice and order. The notice and order shall be served on the person personally, or by certified mail and regular mail to the person's residence, regular place of business or last known address. If the certified or regular mail is returned undelivered, a copy shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or on the person's residence, regular place of business, last known address, or the property affected. 
C.  No person shall throw into or deposit in any water closet, privy or privy vault, any offal, garbage or swill, or any hard, solid matter. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 532-2000) 
94.53 - Fixtures for water closets. 
    No person, in possession of premises into which a pipe or other connection with a sewer or drain has been laid for the purpose of carrying off refuse from privies or water closets, slops from kitchens, or for other purposes, shall allow the same to remain without good and perfect fixtures, so attached as to allow a sufficient amount of water to carry off such matter and to keep such pipe and other connection unobstructed. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.54 - Water supply. 
    All water closets, basins, traps, and urinals shall be provided with a sufficient supply of water to insure the cleaning of the same after each use, and all traps connected therewith shall be effectively sealed. In no case shall any such closet, basin, or urinal be used longer than one hour without such water supply if, from any cause, the same is cut off, unless water is supplied from some other source. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.55 - Abandoned wells. 
    No person shall use any abandoned well as a sink or privy vault. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.56 - Transportation of excreta-Receptacles and vehicles. 
A.  No person shall transport the contents of any sink, privy vault, septic tank, or other filthy place, or any soluble excreta on any street, alley, or other public place except in an airtight and watertight tank or apparatus that prevents the contents from emitting nauseous or unwholesome odors, vapors, or gases. 
B.  No person in charge of a vehicle for the removal of excreta shall allow the same to stand on any street, alley, or public ground of the City, except while loading. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.57 - Open flow of waste prohibited. 
    No person shall cause or permit any septic tank effluent or waste of any kind to flow onto adjoining property, into a public street or into the open unless such person has written approval to do so from the Director of Health. Penalty, see  94.99. Ord. 182-1963) 
94.58 - Septic tanks required where sewers not available. 
    Where no sanitary sewer is available for connection with any building, septic tanks of an approved type must be installed. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.59 - Erection of privy vaults-Percolation test required. 
    No privy vault shall be erected in connection with any building unless a percolation test shows that the formation of the soil is unsuitable for proper functioning of a septic tank. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.60 - Installation and alteration-Permit required. 
    No person shall install or alter a privy vault, septic tank, leach bed, leach well, tile field, or other secondary treatment designed for septic tank effluent without first obtaining a permit to do so from the Director of Health. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.61 - Lapse of permit. 
    If work for which a permit required by  94.60 is issued is not started within six months of the date of issue, or if such work is not completed within seven months of the date of issue, the permit shall lapse and cease to be in effect. 
94.62 - Permit fees. 
    The fee for the permit required by  94.60 shall be as follows: For privy vaults, three dollars; for septic tanks, three dollars; for leach bed, leach well, tile field, or other secondary treatment designed for septic tank effluent, three dollars; for simultaneous installation of septic tank and leach bed, leach well, filter bed, or other secondary treatment designed for septic tank effluent, five dollars. 
94.63 - Failure to obtain permit. 
    Whenever a person willfully commences the installation or alteration of any privy vault, septic tank, leach bed, filter bed, leach well, or other secondary treatment designed for septic tank effluent, without first obtaining a permit as provided for in  94.60, such person, in addition to the penalty, shall be subject to payment of fifty percent in addition to the regular fee for work to be done under such permit. However, the payment of such fifty percent shall not exempt such person from compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.64 - Construction requirements. 
A.  All vaults or septic tanks shall be watertight and constructed of either eight-inch brick or six-inch concrete or such other reinforced concrete as is approved by the Director of Health. The walls of such vaults or septic tanks, if made of brick, shall be of hard-turned sewer brick, not less than eight inches thick, laid in portland cement mortar; the walls and bottom shall be plastered outside and inside with a one-half inch coat of portland cement mortar, in proportion of one part of portland cement and two parts of clean sharp sand. After this coating is put on it shall be given one coat of wash with liquid portland cement. The bottom shall have at least three brick courses laid in cement mortar or shall be of portland cement concrete mortar eight inches thick and plastered as above. 
B.  When portland cement concrete is used to construct vaults or septic tanks, the walls shall be at least six inches thick, laid to a form, and the concrete shall be made of one part of live portland cement, three parts of clean sharp sand, five parts of crushed stones, free from dust and of sizes between 1/4 and 1-1/2 inches in largest diameter, and shall be plastered and grouted inside and out as prescribed above for brick construction. 
C.  Vaults shall be made watertight and their walls continued twelve inches above the ground surface to prevent surface drainage. No retempered cement shall be used. 
D.  The vault shall be of such a shape and size as not to extend under any portion of the floor of the outhouse, but only under the space occupied by the seats. Any portion of the vault extending beyond the walls of the outhouse shall be covered by a four-inch brick arch, four inches above flagging, a reinforced concrete slab or cast iron. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.65 - Capacity of septic tanks. 
    Every septic tank shall have a working capacity sufficient to serve the building for which it is intended or to which it is connected and shall be approved by the Director of Health or the Director of the Division of Sanitation. However, no tank shall have a capacity of less than one thousand gallons. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 293-1954) 
94.66 - Leach beds and wells-Tile fields. 
A.  The outlet of every septic tank shall be connected to a leach bed, leach well, or tile field, of a size and design approved by the Director of Health or the Director of Sanitation as satisfactory for use at the place of installation. 
1.  Leach wells may be permitted where the effluent will drain safely into sand, gravel, or other permeable subsoil formations. 
2.  Leach beds of the following minimum bottom sizes may be installed where percolation tests made according to standards prescribed by the U.S. Public Health Service show a fall of water of one inch in less than thirty minutes: 
Dwelling Type Size (Square Feet) Two-bedroom 180 Three-bedroom 240 Four-bedroom 300  
3.  If the formation and composition of the soil do not permit the installation of a leach well or a leach bed, a tile field of five hundred lineal feet (one thousand square feet bottom measurement) may be installed, if approved by the Director of Health or the Director of Sanitation. 
B.  Leach wells and leach beds may be installed only in lots with sufficient open area to accommodate two such installations. Tile fields shall be installed only in lots having a minimum area of fifteen thousand square feet. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 699-1961) 
94.67 - Location of vaults. 
    No privy vault shall be constructed within fifty feet of any building occupied, used, designed, or intended as a dwelling place, nor within fifty feet of any water well or cistern. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.68 - Location of septic tanks. 
    No septic tanks shall be constructed within twenty feet of any building occupied, used, designed, or intended as a dwelling place, nor within fifty feet of any water well or cistern. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.69 - Outhouses. 
    Over each privy vault, which shall receive nothing but human excreta, there shall be placed an outhouse. The seats shall be provided with tightly fitting covers. Under each end of the seats there shall be provided a vent opening at least three inches in diameter, covered with not less than number 18 wire mesh. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.70 - Use of new devices. 
    Any new device for the disposal or receiving of human excreta which meets with the approval of the Director of Health may be constructed and used. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.71 - Inspection of installations. 
    No person shall conceal or cover any septic tank, leach well, leach bed, filter bed, or other secondary treatment designed for septic tank effluent installation until a thorough inspection of the same has been made and until the work has been approved by the Director of Health. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.72 - Notification to inspect installation. 
    Whenever any work or installation specified in this chapter is ready for inspection, the person for whom the permit was issued shall notify the Department of Public Health not later than 4:00 p.m. on the working day prior to the day on which the inspection is desired. 
94.73 - Condemnation of defective vaults or tanks-Notice. 
A.  Whenever it comes to the attention of the Director of Health that any privy vault, septic tank, leach bed, leach well, filter bed or other secondary treatment designed for septic tank effluent has become bad, defective, unsanitary, unsafe, faulty or liable to breed disease or endanger the property or health of residents of the community, the Director shall make an inspection of the same. If it is found to be defective or unsanitary, he shall condemn the same, notify the owner, agent or occupant in writing and designate the repairs required to be made. The repairs or improvements shall be made within the time ordered. The notice and order shall be served on the person personally, or by certified mail and regular mail to the person's residence, regular place of business or last known address. If the certified mail or regular mail is returned undelivered, a copy shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or on the person's residence, regular place of business, last known address, or the property affected. 
B.  No person shall live in, occupy or use the building or structure served by the septic tank, vault, leach bed, leach well, tile field, or other secondary treatment designed for septic tank effluent, while the same are so condemned. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 532-2000) 
94.74 - Connections between septic tanks and buildings. 
    All connections between septic tanks and the buildings which they serve shall be constructed, installed, and maintained in accordance with the requirements of the plumbing regulations of the building code. Penalty, see  94.99. 
Article 4. - Lead Poisoning Hazards 

94.80 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "Child care facility." Any place in which children under six years of age are cared for by persons other than their parents or guardians, custodians, or relatives by blood, marriage, or adoption for any part of the twenty-four hour day in a place or residence other than a child's own home. 
    "Child with lead poisoning." A child or children six years of age and younger with a confirmed blood level greater than or equal to ten micrograms g M of lead per deciliter (dL) of whole blood (g M/dL) or such lower blood lead level as may be recommended by the Department of Health and Human Services, Public Health Center, Centers for Disease Control (CDC). 
    "Director of Health." The Director of Health of the City or his duly authorized delegate or representative. 
    "Dust-lead hazard." A dust-lead hazard is present when: 
1.  Lead-contaminated dust on floors contains forty g/ft 2 (micrograms per square foot) or more lead or such lead content that may be recommended by the Director of Health or may hereafter be established by federal law or regulation; 
2.  Lead-contaminated dust on interior window sills or on any other interior accessible surface contains 250 g/ft 2 (micrograms per square foot) or more lead or such lead content that may be recommended by the Director of Health or may hereafter be established by federal law or regulation; 
3.  Lead-contaminated dust in window troughs (window wells) contains 400 g/ft 2 (micrograms per square foot) or more lead or such lead content that may be recommended by the Director of Health or may hereafter be established by federal law or regulation. 
    "Dwelling." A structure all or part of which is designed for human habitation. 
    "Dwelling unit." Any room, group of rooms, or other interior area of a structure designed or used for human habitation. 
    "Exposed surface." In or on a dwelling unit, an exterior surface that is readily accessible to children. 
    "Lead based coatings." Any paint, lacquer, or other applied liquid surface coating or putty which contains more than five thousand ppm lead by weight calculated as lead metal in the total nonvolatile content of liquid paints; or one milligram or more per square centimeter as measured by an analytical device or procedure approved by the Director of Health, or such standard as may hereafter be established by federal law or regulation. 
    "Lead-bearing substance." Any structural substance or material which contains more than five thousand ppm lead by weight calculated as lead metal in the total nonvolatile content of liquid paints; or one milligram or more per square centimeter as measured by an analytical device or procedure approved by the Director of Health, or such standard as may hereafter be established by federal law or regulation. 
    "Occupant." Any person who is living, sleeping, cooking, eating in, or actually having possession of a dwelling unit or a rooming unit, except in dwelling units a guest will not be considered an occupant. 
    "Owner." Any person who alone, jointly, or severally with others: 
1.  Shall have legal title to any premises, dwelling, or dwelling unit with or without accompanying actual possession thereof; or 
2.  Shall have charge, care, or control of any premises, dwelling, or dwelling unit as owner or agent of the owner, or an executor, administrator, trustee, or guardian of the estate of the owner. 
    "Person." Any individual, firm, corporation, association, or partnership. 
    "Premises." The dwelling and any other building of any kind or nature located on the lot, as well as the entire parcel of land surrounding such buildings, including but not limited to, fences, walkways, walls, and appurtenances. 
    "Rubbish." Nonputrescible solid wastes (excluding ashes) consisting of either: 
1.  Combustible wastes, such as old batteries, paint scraping, paper, cardboard, plastic containers, yard clippings, and wood; or 
2.  Noncombustible wastes, such as tin cans, glass, and crockery. 
    "Safety." The condition of being free from danger and hazards that may cause accidents or disease. 
    "Soil-lead hazard." A soil-lead hazard is present when: 
1.  Lead-contaminated bare soil within the building perimeter and yard contains two thousand ppm (parts per million) or more lead; or such lead content that may be recommended by the Director of Health or may hereafter be established by federal law or regulation. 
2.  Lead-contaminated bare soil within play areas and high-contact areas contains four hundred ppm (parts per million) or more lead; or such lead content that may be recommended by the Director of Health or may hereafter be established by federal law or regulation. 
    "Solid wastes." All putrescible and nonputrescible solids (except body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, and dead animals. 
    "Surface." The outermost layer or superficial area of a dwelling or dwelling units, including, but not limited to, the outermost layer or superficial area of the walls, ceilings, floors, stairs, windows, window sills, window frames, window sashes, doors, and door frames. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 523-2002; Ord. 671-1992; Ord. 167-1988; Ord. 9-1979) 
94.81 - Prohibited conduct. 
A.  No occupant or owner shall use or apply any lead-based coating: 
1.  In or on any exposed surface of any dwelling, dwelling unit, outbuilding, or child care facility. 
2.  In or on any fixtures or other objects used, installed, or located in or on any exposed surface of any dwelling or dwelling unit. 
3.  In or on toys, cooking, drinking, or eating utensils, or furniture. 
B.  No occupant or owner shall use, or permit the use of any lead-bearing substance in or on any dwelling or dwelling unit or allow leadbearing substance to remain in or on any dwelling unit. 
C.  No occupant or owner shall deposit, cause to be deposited, maintain, or otherwise create a dust-lead hazard or soil-lead hazard at a premises of any dwelling, dwelling unit, outbuilding or child care facility. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 523-2002; Ord. 167-1988; Ord. 9-1979) 
94.82 - Reporting requirement. 
    No person shall fail to report to the Health Director a child suspected of or diagnosed as having increased lead absorption and/or lead poisoning. 
(Ord. 167-1988) 
94.83 - Disposal of lead-bearing substances. 
A.  Disposal of lead-bearing substances, their ashes, and other refuse shall comply with procedures established by the Director of Health. 
B.  Open burning of batteries, battery cases, and other materials with heavy accumulations of lead is prohibited. 
C.  Utilization wood painted with lead-based coatings is prohibited also. 
D.  Contaminated soil shall be either turned under at least twelve inches deep or removed and replaced with clean fill dirt or top soil. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 167-1988; Ord. 9-1979) 
94.84 - Inspections. 
    The Director of Health or his duly authorized representative may at any reasonable time, enter a dwelling or dwelling unit where a child with increased lead absorption resides and may remove samples for analysis to determine whether lead-based coatings or leadbearing substances are present. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 167-1988; Ord. 9-1979) 
94.85 - Removal of lead-based coatings. 
A.  Where the Director of Health or his duly authorized representative determines that the presence of lead-based coatings or leadbearing substances upon any premise creates a health hazard to children, he shall issue an order to the owner or occupant to eliminate the hazard. 
B.  Lead-based coatings shall be completely removed from any surface which can be chewed or eaten by children. Cracked, chipped, blistered, or peeling lead-based coatings shall be completely removed to the bare surface under such safety conditions as may be approved by the Director of Health. 
C.  In lieu of removal of the lead-based coatings, the accessible surface shall be covered with an approved durable material. 
D.  Repainting a surface with a nonleaded coating without complete removal of the existing lead paint shall not be deemed to be a satisfactory compliance with this section. 
E.  The methods used for the removal of lead-based coatings shall not present a hazard to health from fumes, dust, or vapors by inhalation or absorption through the skin and mucous membranes or by the contamination of soil surrounding the abatement area. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 167-1988; Ord. 9-1979) 
94.86 - Permit requirements. 
A.  Persons who are required to comply with any provisions of  94.85 or persons conducting renovation or rehabilitation activities that are covered by  94.85 shall first obtain a permit therefor from the Director of Health. 
1.  Permit applications shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of five dollars to help defray the costs of processing the application. 
2.  A minimum five-day notice shall be given to the Department of Health before any power sanding, sandblasting, or power washing methods for the purpose of removal of paint or lead hazard reduction are being utilized. 
3.  The Department of Health may require testing of surfaces prior to the start of renovation, safety precautions for workers, occupants, neighbors, and the public depending upon the nature and extent of lead hazard removal. 
B.  The methods of removal being utilized shall be in compliance with the Fugitive Dust Law regulated by the Air Pollution Control Regulations so as to prevent the uncontrolled dispersal of lead-bearing dust into the air and soil. 
C.  The Department of Health shall have the authority to conduct soil sampling or any other environmental lead sampling it may deem necessary in order to enforce regulations relating to fugitive dust and debris. 
D.  The Department of Health shall have the authority to issue an immediate cease-work order to any person or company found in violation of any of the provisions of this section. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 1037-1991) 
94.87 - Notice of violation. 
A.  Whenever the Director of Health or his authorized representative determines there has been a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, he shall give notice of the violation to the person responsible therefor and order compliance, as herein provided. The notice and order shall: 
1.  Be put in writing on an appropriate form; 
2.  Include a list of violations, refer to the section violated and order remedial action which will effect compliance with the provisions of this chapter; 
3.  Specify a reasonable time within which to comply, giving due consideration to the immediacy of the threat to the health of the child with increased lead absorption; and 
4.  Be served on the owner, occupant, or agent personally, or by certified mail and regular mail to the person's residence, regular place of business or last known address. If the certified or regular mail is returned undelivered, a copy shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or on the person's residence, regular place of business, last known address or the property affected. 
B.  Whenever an occupant or owner violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter, the Director of Health or his designee shall have the authority to impose an administrative penalty. The Director of Health or his designee shall consider the following criteria in assessing an administrative penalty: 
1.  The extent to which the person has benefited by the violation of this article; 
2.  The degree of harm to the public health, safety, and welfare as a result of the violation of this article; 
3.  The recidivism of the person, including previous notices and orders to comply and previous enforcement actions; 
4.  Good faith efforts of the person to remedy the violation of this article; and 
5.  The duration of the violation after a notice and order to comply was served pursuant to this section. 
C.  The imposition of an administrative fine shall be accomplished only after a notice and order is provided to the occupant or owner. Notice of a decision imposing an administrative fine shall: 
1.  Be put in writing on an appropriate form as the Department of Public Health shall determine; 
2.  State the basis for the administrative penalty, including the section of this article that has been violated; 
3.  Specify the date and manner by which the penalty must be paid; and 
4.  Be served on the occupant or owner personally or by certified mail and regular mail to the person's residence, regular place of business or last known address. If the certified or regular mail is returned undelivered, a copy shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or on the person's residence, regular place of business, last known address, or the dwelling affected. 
(Ord. 523-2002; Ord. 532-2000; Ord. 1037-1991; Ord. 167-1988; Ord. 9-1979) 
94.871 - Administrative penalty. 
A.  In addition to any criminal penalties that may be imposed pursuant to  94.99(A), any occupant or owner who violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be subject to the following administrative penalties in accordance with the criteria stated in  94.87(B) of this chapter. 
1.  For a first offense, an administrative fine of up to one hundred dollars; 
2.  For a second offense, an administrative fine of up to five hundred dollars; 
3.  For a third offense, an administrative fine of up to one thousand dollars. 
B.  If an occupant or owner fails, neglects or refuses to pay an administrative penalty within the time ordered pursuant to  94.87 of this chapter, then the Director of Health shall so notify the Director of Finance. The Director of Finance shall certify the administrative penalty to the County Auditor. In addition to the administrative penalty, an interest rate equal to the current rate of interest charged by the City on special assessments shall be imposed by the City for the life of the administrative penalty, added to the administrative penalty and collected as provided in this section. The Director of Finance shall then certify the amount of the administrative penalty, including interest, to the County Auditor. The County Auditor shall then enter the amount on the tax duplicate of the county as a special assessment against the rest estate at issue. 
(Ord. 523-2003) 
94.88 - Appeals procedures. 
A.  Any person affected by any notice of violation from the Director of Health may request and shall be granted a hearing before the Director of Health provided the request for such a hearing is made within the time specified in the notice mentioned in  94.86. 
B.  After such hearing, the Director of Health shall sustain, modify, or withdraw the notice of alleged violation depending on his findings as to whether the provisions of this regulation have been complied with. Notice of the decision of the Director of Health shall be served on the persons and in the manner as provided in  94.86. 
C.  1.  Any person affected by the decision of the Health Director as provided in subsection B of this section, shall be entitled to appeal the decision of Director of Health to the Health Commission. Written notice of the appeal must be filed with the secretary of the Health Commission within five days of the personal service, or date of posting and shall state the order appealed from and the address to which the hearing notice shall be mailed. The Health Commission shall hear the appeal at the next regular meeting of the Board of Health provided that no hearing shall be had sooner than five days from the date of the filing of the notice of appeal. Notice of the meeting for the Health Commission at which the appeal is to be heard shall be given to the appellant by regular mail at the address shown in his notice of appeal. The appellant shall be entitled to appear personally and with counsel, at the meeting of the Health Commission. The Health Commission may, in its discretion, continue the hearing on the appeal from time to time until the hearing is completed. 
2.  The Health Commission shall modify, withdraw, or sustain the order of the Director of Health made pursuant to subsection B of this section. The copy of the decision of the Health Commission shall be mailed to the appellant at the address shown in the notice of appeal, and to his counsel of record. 
D.  Emergency Situation. Whenever the Director finds that an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, he may, without notice or hearing, issue an order stating the existence of such an emergency and requiring that such action be taken as he deems necessary to meet the emergency. Such order shall be effective immediately. Any person to whom such order is directed shall comply therewith immediately, but, on petition to the Director, shall be afforded a hearing as soon as possible. After such hearing, depending on his finding as to whether or not the emergency condition has been abated, the Director shall continue such order in effect or modify or revoke it. 
(Ord. 1037-1991; Ord. 167-1988; Ord. 9-1979) 
94.89 - Placard. 
    If, after the time ordered for compliance in the notification to the owner, the removal of lead-based coating or lead-bearing substances has not begun, the Director of Health shall cause to be posted on the dwelling or dwelling unit identified in the notification a notice of the existence of such coatings or substances and the declaration that the dwelling or dwelling unit is unfit for human habitation for those persons under six years of age. The dwelling or dwelling unit shall remain posted until the owner has complied with the orders. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 167-1988; Ord. 9-1979) 
94.90 - Retaliation prohibited. 
    No owner or agent of an owner of rental property shall take retaliatory action against a tenant because of enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter nor evict or attempt to evict a tenant as retaliation or to avoid compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Penalty, see  94.99. 
(Ord. 1037-1991; Ord. 167-1988; Ord. 9-1979) 
94.91 - Conflict and invalidity. 
    In any case where a provision of this article is found to be in conflict with a provision of any zoning, building, fire, safety, or health ordinance or code of the City existing on the effective date of this article, the provision which established the higher standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people shall prevail. In any case, where a provision of this article is found to be in conflict with a provision of any other ordinance or code of the City existing on the effective date of this article which established a lower standard for the promotion and protection of the health and safety of the people, the provisions of this article shall be deemed to prevail, and such other ordinances or codes are declared to be repealed to the extent that they may be found in conflict with this chapter. 
(Ord. 1037-1991; Ord. 167-1988; Ord. 9-1979) 
Article 5. - Heating Regulations 

94.95 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "Apartment." All buildings or parts thereof designed, constructed, altered, or converted to be used as places of residence for three or more families, living separately from each other but within the same building, and having common rights in halls, yards, stairs, lobbies, or other like areas. 
    "Hotel." All buildings or parts thereof designed, constructed, altered, or converted for the accommodation of resident or transient guests, in which ten or more rooms with sleeping accommodations are offered for pay to such guests. 
    "Office building." All buildings or parts thereof designed, constructed, altered, or converted for use for office purposes and offering such accommodation for pay to three or more tenants. 
    "Owner." Every person, firm, corporation, or fiduciary, or their managers, agents, or employees, who have the ownership, management, operation, or control of a hotel, apartment, or office building. 
94.96 - Minimum heat required-Liability of owner. 
A.  Every owner of a hotel, apartment, or office building shall furnish heat sufficient to maintain the following minimum temperatures: 
1.  In hotels and apartments, between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 11:00 p.m., 70 F.; between the hours of 11:00 p. m. and 6:00 a.m., 65 F.; 
2.  In office buildings, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., 70 F. 
B.  The requirements of this section do not apply to any lobby, corridor, stairway, or other similar area; nor to any room, suite of rooms, or office not occupied by guests or tenants for pay; nor to any room, suite of rooms, or office provided with a separate heating plant under the care and control of the tenant or occupant thereof. 
C.  Each period of more than three consecutive hours during which the owner of a hotel, apartment, or office building fails to provide the heat required by this section shall constitute a violation thereof. Penalty, see  94.99. 
94.97 - Exceptions. 
    An owner shall not be held to have violated  94.96 if his failure to provide the required heat is due to a breakdown in a heating plant or other cause beyond the control of such owner, nor shall he be held liable when a steam or other heating company fails, for whatever reason, to provide steam or other heat as specified under contract with such owner. 
94.98 - Administration and enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article shall be administered by the Director of Health. Upon receipt of a complaint that any of the provisions hereof have been, or are being, violated, the Director shall investigate the complaint, and, on being satisfied of the truth thereof, shall order the violation to cease.
