Any person engaged in business as an itinerant retailer on private property, belonging to another, must have the written permission, on a form to be prescribed by the City License Clerk, of the property owner. The itinerant retailer shall carry the form with his itinerant retailer's license while he is engaged in business as an itinerant retailer. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 867-1985; Ord. 235-1984; Ord. 318-1983) 
111.346 - License display upon police request. 
    Every grantee of a license under this article shall, when so requested by any member of the Police Division, produce such license for inspection. 
(Ord. 867-1985; Ord. 318-1983) 
111.347 - Proximity to schools-Sales on roadways-Disposal of wrappers. 
A.  No itinerant retailer shall park, stand, or stop, for the purpose of making a sale, within one thousand feet of any school property, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. on school days. 
B.  No itinerant retailer shall make a sale or delivery to any person while such person is standing in the roadway. 
C.  No itinerant retailer may solicit or conduct business with persons in motor vehicles. 
D.  Each itinerant retailer or his vehicle shall be equipped with a receptacle for the disposal of wrappers, papers or envelopes or other containers. No itinerant retailer shall fail to pick up such wrappers, papers and envelopes after any sale or delivery of his product. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 867-1985; Ord. 235-1984; Ord. 318-1983) 
111.348 - Sale from vehicles. 
    No itinerant retailer shall stop his motor vehicle on a street or highway of the City for the purpose of offering to sell anything of value. Exempted from this section shall be ice cream trucks falling within the purview of  111.200(A), and mobile food service vendors falling within the purview of  111.368, et seq. For the purpose of this section street or highway shall include those portions of the street or highway commonly referred to as the shoulder. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 867-1985; Ord. 318-1983) 
(Ord. 150-2014) 
111.349 - Use of loudspeakers on vehicles. 
    No person shall use a loudspeaker on a vehicle, trailer, or bicycle for any purpose on any street or alley of the City after 8:00 p.m. or before 11:00 a.m. Nothing in this section shall be construed to preclude the application of  110.10 or  132.16 of this code. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 214-1993; Ord. 113-1991; Ord. 867-1985; Ord. 318-1983) 
111.350 - Insurance. 
A.  No license required by  111.341 shall be issued to a vendor falling within the purview of  111.200(A) (Ice Cream Trucks) unless a certificate showing that he is carrying the following minimum amounts of insurance naming the City as an additional insured is furnished to the city: Public liability insurance in the amount of not less than five hundred thousand dollars for property damage and injuries, including those resulting in death, resulting in any one occurrence. 
B.  No license required by  111.341 shall be issued to any vendor unless a certificate showing that he is carrying the following minimum amounts of insurance naming the City as an additional insured is furnished to the city: Public liability insurance in an amount not less than one hundred thousand dollars for property damage and injuries, including those resulting in death, resulting in any one occurrence. 
C.  Certificate shall contain an agreement signed by the insurance company that prior to modification, cancellation, or termination of the policy, written notice shall be sent to the City License Clerk by the insurance company at least ten days in advance of such modification, cancellation, or termination. 
(Ord. 867-1985; Ord. 235-1984; Ord. 318-1983) 
111.351 - Hours of sale. 
(A)  Except as provided in Section (B) of this section, no person licensed under  111.341 shall sell or offer to sell, in the parks and on or from the street, sidewalks, and alleys of the City anything of value between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
(B)  No person licensed under  111.341 shall sell or offer to sell, in the parks and on or from the street, sidewalks, and alleys within the community entertainment district of the City anything of value between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 10:00 a.m. 
(Ord. 867-1985; Ord. 318-1983) 
(Ord. No. 492-2009,  1, 11-16-09) 
111.352 - Exemptions. 
A.  1.  Persons holding sales of used personal property on or within their premises shall be exempted from application of this article. 
2.  Personal property shall mean property which is owned, utilized and maintained by an individual or members of his residence and acquired in the normal course of living in or maintaining a residence. It does not include merchandise which was purchased for resale or obtained on consignment. 
B.  Nonprofit organizations with a local place of business shall be exempted from application of this article. 
(Ord. 214-1993; Ord. 867-1985; Ord. 394-1983) 
111.353 - Prohibited conduct. 
A.  No merchandise shall be displayed or sold within ten feet of a: 
1.  Doorway or entranceway or within ten feet of prolongation of a doorway or entranceway to the curbline; 
2.  Crosswalk; 
3.  Designated bus stop; 
4.  Fire hydrant; or 
5.  Curbcut. 
B.  No merchandise shall be displayed on any utility pole, planter, tree, trash container, public bench, or other sidewalk fixture. 
C.  No merchandise shall be displayed or sold in any manner that blocks, obstructs, or restricts the free passage of pedestrians in the lawful use of sidewalks. 
D.  Sidewalk vendors must contain their stand, including merchandise and supplies, within an area no larger than eight feet by six feet. Itinerant retailers selling from locations other than sidewalks shall have combined sales and display areas no larger than twelve feet by twelve feet. 
E.  No trailer may be placed on any sidewalk. (See  152.01 for definition of trailer.) 
F.  No advertising, except the posting of prices, shall be permitted on or by any stand or motor vehicle other than to identify merchandise offered for sale or to identify itinerant retailer. 
G.  No itinerant retailers shall operate within the boundaries of a designated special event or public property without the express permission of the sponsor of the general event. Itinerant retailers operating in special events are exempt from the license requirement during the event. Designated special events shall include only those events for which the written approval of the Mayor or Service Director has been obtained for the use of public property for the special event. The Mayor and Service Director may grant permission for the use of the public property for special events sponsored by community service organizations and nonprofit corporations. A map designating the boundaries of the public property being utilized for the special event must be submitted to the Chief of Police and to the Licensing Clerk after the special event has been approved. 
H.  No itinerant retailer shall operate in any one location for more than three consecutive days. 
I.  Itinerant retailers shall remove all equipment, vehicles and price postings from their places of operation at the end of each day. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 214-1993; Ord. 867-1985; Ord. 295-1984; Ord. 235-1984) 
111.354 - Denial, suspension, and revocation. 
    Any license may be denied, suspended, or revoked in accordance with the procedure contained in this article for any of the following causes: 
A.  Fraud or misrepresentation contained in the application for the license. 
B.  Fraud or misrepresentation made in the course of carrying on the business of vending. 
C.  Conduct of the licensed business in such manner as to create a public nuisance, or constitute a danger to the public health, safety, welfare, or morals. 
D.  Conduct which is contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. 867-1985; Ord. 235-1984) 
111.355 - Food itinerant retailers. 
A.  Food itinerant retailers cooking on open-flame grills on site must provide fire retardant barriers between cooking device and pedestrians and adjoining property. 
B.  No more than one twenty-pound liquid petroleum cylinder may be attached to the vehicle or appliance at any time. No spare liquid petroleum cylinders may be kept within the peddling area as specified in  111.353. The liquid petroleum cylinder shall be mounted in a well-ventilated compartment attached to the vehicle. 
C.  An ABC rated fire extinguisher of a five-pound or greater capacity shall be mounted on the outside of the cart vehicle opposite the burner unit. 
(Ord. 867-1985; Ord. 295-1984) 
Article 21A. - Door to Door Peddling and Solicitation 

111.360 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
A.  "Peddling" means calling at residences without an invitation or previous consent of the owner or occupant of such premises for the purpose of any one or more of the following activities: 
1.  Seeking for profit to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs or services of any kind, character or description whatsoever, for either present or future delivery; 
2.  Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of any type, kind or character; 
3.  Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and every other kind or type of publication. 
B.  "Solicitation" means: 
1.  Seeking to obtain from an occupant of any residence an indication of such occupant's belief in regard to any social, political or religious matters; 
2.  Seeking to obtain contributions or sell any goods, articles or services of any kind for the support or benefit of any educational, civic, philanthropic, charitable, religious or non-profit association, organization, corporation or project; 
3.  Seeking to influence the personal belief of the occupant of any residence in regard to any social, political or religious matter; or 
4.  Taking a poll or census by any person, firm or corporation, other than a governmental body or agency thereof, and excluding commercial polls. 
(Ord. 421-2007) 
(Ord. 274-2012) 
111.361 - Hours of peddling and solicitation regulated. 
    No peddling or solicitation shall be conducted before 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. when daylight savings time is in effect nor after 8:00 p.m. during the remainder of the year. 
(Ord. 421-2007) 
(Ord. 274-2012) 
111.362 - Peddling in residential districts. 
    No person shall enter upon the lot or land of any residence for the purpose of peddling as defined in Section 111.360(A) unless such person has registered and has in his possession the valid, current registration issued in accordance with the provisions of  111.363. 
(Ord. 421-2007) 
111.363 - Registration of credentials for peddlers-Application fee. 
A.  Whoever desires to engage in peddling as defined in Section 111.360(A) shall register his credentials and shall submit in duplicate with the License and Assessments Clerk a written application on a form to be provided by the License and Assessments Clerk, along with a valid driver's license or identification card issued by the State of Ohio or any other state for inspection and copying, correctly setting forth the following information: 
1.  The full name, address, and social security number of the applicant; 
2.  Whether or not he or she uses any motor vehicle(s) in his or her business, and if so, the make(s), model(s), year(s) and current registration number(s) thereof; 
3.  The name, address and phone number of his or her business or employer, and a contact person therein; 
4.  A brief description of the goods, wares, merchandise or services involved; and 
5.  Whether or not he or she has ever been convicted of any crime, other than a traffic offense, and if so, the nature thereof and the penalty therefor. 
B.  Concurrently with the filing of the application, the applicant shall pay a fee of thirty-five dollars to the License and Assessments Clerk to compensate for the costs incident to the examination, registration and issuance of stamped copies of credentials. 
C.  Registration shall be approved within five business days after receipt of the completed application unless: 
1.  The applicant has provided false information in his or her application; and/or 
2.  The applicant named on the application has been convicted of a felony violation or misdemeanor violation as set forth in Subsection (G) of this section within the past five years. 
    Such registration shall be stamped with the date of expiration which in each case shall be the close of the current calendar year or six months, whichever is later. 
D.  Once issued, registration may be used only in conformity with the laws of the City and the State of Ohio; may not be assigned or transferred; must be carried by the peddler at all times; and may be revoked for any of the following causes: 
1.  The peddler named in the application or person preparing the application on behalf of the peddler provided false information in the application; and/or 
2.  The peddler is convicted of a felony or misdemeanor as set forth in Subsection (G). 
E.  Possession of registration credentials shall not entitle the applicant to enter upon any lot or land specified in Section 111.364 between the hours of sunset and 9:00 a.m. nor shall such credentials be valid for the peddling of any goods or services not disclosed in the original application. 
F.  Any person who has not reached eighteen years of age shall be required to have a parent, guardian or employer co-sign on the application. 
G.  Any person who has been convicted of or who has plead guilty to any criminal offense of the Ohio Revised Code, United States Code, or any other substantially similar state or local code provisions that constitute any theft or fraud offense, any offense of burglary, any offenses of violence, or any offenses of any sex crime law or statute within the last five years is prohibited from peddling within the City of Akron. 
(Ord. 421-2007) 
111.364 - Notice prohibiting peddling. 
A.  Notice by the owner or occupant of any residence of the determination to refuse to receive any uninvited peddlers shall be given by displaying a card, decal or sign, not less than two inches by three inches in size nor more than one square foot in total surface area, upon or near the main entrance door to the residence, indicating such determination by the owner or occupant, containing the words "No Solicitors," or words of similar import, with letters at least 1/3 of an inch in height. Any such sign that complies with the requirements of this section shall be exempt from any additional or different requirements contained in the provisions of this code, including but not limited to the Planning and Zoning Code. 
(Ord. 421-2007) 
111.365 - Peddling in violation of notice. 
    It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to go upon any premises and ring the door bell upon or near any door, rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of any occupant of such residence for the purpose of peddling in defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of  111.364, unless the peddler has been previously invited upon the premises by the owner, lessee, or an adult occupant thereof. 
(Ord. 421-2007) 
111.366 - False information-Revocation of registration-Appeals of denial or revocation. 
A.  No person shall make any false statement or give any false or misleading information in the application required by Section 111.363. 
B.  If a registration is denied or revoked, the License Clerk shall notify the holder thereof either in person or by certified mail of the actions so taken. Such remedy shall be in addition to the penalty provided in Section 111.999. 
C.  Appeals. Any applicant shall have the right to appeal the denial or revocation of registration by requesting a review. The appeal shall be taken by the applicant or registration holder within ten days after issuance of the notice of denial or revocation by filing written notice of appeal with the Mayor. The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the provisions of Section 110.02 within a reasonable time period not to exceed thirty days after filing of the notice of appeal. The hearing officer shall direct that the denial or revocation be rescinded if the applicant has met all of the qualifying criteria set forth in this section. The applicant or registration holder may appeal the decision of the hearing officer to the court of common pleas of Summit County pursuant to Chapter 2506 of the Ohio Revised Code. 
(Ord. 421-2007) 
111.367 - Display of credentials. 
A.  Every holder of registered credentials, when engaged in peddling upon any lot or land of any residence shall, upon the request of any owner or occupant of a residence, present for examination his credentials issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
B.  Every holder of registered and stamped credentials shall prominently display his or her credentials in a conspicuous place upon his or her person at all times while peddling pursuant to this section. 
C.  The Licenses and Assessments Clerk shall cause a weatherproof credential of sufficient size and color to be given to each approved applicant herein. 
(Ord. 421-2007) 
Article 21B. - Mobile Retail Food Establishments 

111.368 - Definitions. 
A.  As used in this chapter, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the context: 
1.  "Mobile retail food establishment" means a retail food establishment that is operated from a movable vehicle or other portable structure, and that routinely changes location. 
(Ord. 150-2014) 
111.369 - Mobile retail food establishments-Permits and fees. 
A.  Permit Required. No vendor of a mobile retail food establishment shall sell, offer for sale or display food items from City streets, rights-of-way or property without first obtaining a permit from the City License Division. A permit is not required for a vendor participating in a City-sanctioned special event or community event. 
B.  Application. An application for a permit under this section shall be made upon a form prescribed by the Licensing Agent, and contain the following: 
1.  The vendor's name, address, phone number, email address, and mobile retail food establishment license number; 
2.  Tax identification number; 
3.  Proof of a City income tax filing number or exemption from the City of Akron Division of Income Tax; 
4.  Proof that the vendor is current and compliant in the payment of any City of Akron taxes on payroll and net profits at the time such proof is submitted; or if the vendor is not current and compliant in the payment of any City of Akron taxes on payroll and net profits, that vendor has entered into an agreement to pay any delinquency and is abiding by the terms of the agreement at the time such proof is submitted; 
5.  A description of the mobile retail food establishment, including the dimensions; 
6.  A description of the items to be offered for sale; 
7.  A copy of the vendor's mobile retail food establishment license; 
8.  A certificate of insurance, or an acknowledgment thereof, by an insurance carrier licensed to do business in this state, evidencing comprehensive general liability coverage in the amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000) to protect against damage to property and/or persons resulting from the operation of the mobile retail food establishment and naming the City of Akron as an additional insured; 
9.  A non-refundable application fee of two hundred twenty-five dollars ($225); 
10.  Any other information as the Licensing Agent may require. 
C.  Permitted Use. Upon receipt of a permit under Section 111.369(B), the permittee may operate only outside the Biomedical Corridor and in compliance with the regulations contained in this chapter. 
D.  Permit to Operate within the Biomedical Corridor. A vendor that desires to operate within the Biomedical Corridor and that has a valid permit issued under Section 111.369(B) shall be issued a permit to operate within the Biomedical Corridor upon payment of a fee of one thousand seven hundred fifty dollars ($1750). 
E.  The fee for a permit to operate within the biomedical corridor shall be distributed as follows: 
To Summit County 
To Akron Schools 
To Library 
To Metroparks $275 
$1400 
$45 
$30  
F.  Expiration. Permits issued under this section shall be valid for one year from the date of issuance. 
G.  Revocation. The Licensing Agent may suspend or revoke any permit granted under this section on the basis of a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 150-2014) 
111.369.1 - Mobile retail food establishments-Location restrictions. 
A.  No vendor, unless expressly permitted by a permit issued under Section 111.369(D), shall operate a mobile retail food establishment on public property in the following locations: 
1.  On a public sidewalk; 
2.  Within fifty (50) feet of a property occupied by a residence, excluding residences with ground-floor retail space and excluding residences located on the opposite side of a public street; 
3.  Within ten (10) feet of a fire hydrant, bus stop, mail box, telephone booth, building entrance, sidewalk elevator, fire exit or escape, or a police or fire call box; 
4.  Within two hundred (200) feet of the parcel containing a food service business operating from a fixed and permanent location, during operating hours of such business; 
5.  Within fifty (50) feet of the property of a gas station; 
6.  Within seven hundred fifty (750) feet of a park or City-sanctioned special event or community event, except for a mobile retail food establishment that has been authorized to participate at such event; 
7.  Within one thousand (1000) feet of a school; 
8.  In a location where on-street parking is prohibited; or 
9.  Within five (5) feet of another mobile retail food establishment. 
B.  A mobile retail food establishment vendor shall comply with all state and local traffic laws, including Section 76.15 of this Code. 
(Ord. 150-2014) 
111.369.2 - Location restrictions in the biomedical corridor. 
A.  Unless operating under a permit issued under Section 111.369(D), mobile retail food establishments are prohibited from operating on City streets, rights-of-way, and property in the Biomedical Corridor as set forth on a map which shall be a part of this Mobile Retail Food Establishment Code and known as Exhibit 1 and made a part hereof and fully incorporated into this ordinance. Exhibit 1 shall also be permanently on file in the office of the Clerk of Council and shall hereafter be known as Clerk's Document 150-2014, dated May 19, 2014. Upon issuance of a permit to operate in the Biomedical Corridor, a mobile retail food establishment shall be assigned one designated and reserved location to operate within the Biomedical Corridor at one of the following locations: 
1.  Locust Street, south of Cedar Street; 
2.  Park Street, west of Forge Street. 
(Ord. 150-2014) 
111.369.3 - Mobile retail food establishments-Regulations. 
    Mobile retail food establishments shall operate in accordance with the regulations of this section and as otherwise provided by this Code. 
A.  Prohibitions. No mobile retail food establishment vendor shall: 
1.  Sell food items, display food items or conduct vending operations to the occupants of vehicles stopped in traffic; 
2.  Display food items or place lines or other devices for display of food items on any building or on any utility pole, planter, tree, trash container or other sidewalk fixture; 
3.  Place any food items in or upon any street or sidewalk; 
4.  Operate any vending device that does not comply with the Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code, NFPA 58, as promulgated by the National Fire Protection Association; 
5.  Leave a vending device unattended at any time; 
6.  Make any loud or unreasonable noise for the purpose of advertising or drawing attention to its mobile food service operations or for any other purpose; 
7.  Conduct business without making available a container suitable for the placement of litter; 
8.  Throw or deposit any merchandise, packaging, containers, fat, grease, paper or other litter on any streets or sidewalk or in any sewer; or 
9.  Place or affix any advertising material or signage to any location other than flat upon the vending device being used in its operations. 
B.  Requirements. All mobile retail food establishment vendors shall: 
1.  Park parallel to the curb and operate towards the sidewalk; 
2.  Operate only between the hours of 10 a.m. to 12 a.m.; 
3.  Obey any lawful order of a police officer to remove himself or herself and his or her vending device to avoid congestion or obstruction during an emergency; 
4.  Comply with zoning regulations, among other laws, if on private property; 
5.  Exercise reasonable care to ensure that their operations do not create a health or safety hazard to customers, other users of the sidewalks and streets, or persons on abutting property; 
6.  If operating on private property, maintain documentation of the operator's ownership, or if the operator is not the owner of the private property, documentation, signed by the property owner, of the operator's right to operate on the property; 
7.  Obey all federal, state and local laws; and 
8.  Maintain general liability insurance coverage in the amount of one million ($1,000,000) dollars, to protect against damage to property and/or persons resulting from the operation of the mobile retail food establishment. 
(Ord. 150-2014) 
Article 22. - Plasma 

111.370 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "Source plasma (human)." The fluid portion of blood which has been stabilized against clotting, collected by plasmapheresis, and intended as a source material for the further manufacture into blood fractions by fractionation. 
(Ord. 523-1973) 
111.371 - Certification. 
    All establishments engaged in the collection, manufacture, or preparation of source plasma (human) shall apply for certification to the Department of Public Health. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 523-1973) 
111.372 - Shipment-Inspection. 
A.  No person shall sell, barter, or exchange or offer for sale, barter, or exchange any source plasma (human) in or for shipment outside the City unless such source plasma (human) has been collected at an establishment that has received an annual certification from the Department of Public Health. 
B.  The Director of Health shall inspect or cause to be inspected each plasmapheresis center at least quarterly in each year. In the event that the Director finds that any plasmapheresis center is violating any of the provisions of this article, he shall notify the owner or person in charge of such center to appear before him within three days of the service of notice and show cause why the certification of such center should not be revoked. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 523-1973) 
111.373 - Plasmapheresis. 
A.  General Procedure. "Plasmapheresis procedure" means that procedure in which blood is removed from a donor, the plasma is separated from the formed elements and the formed elements are returned to the donor during a single visit to the establishment. The specific plasmapheresis procedure to be used shall be described in detail in the application to the Department of Public Health for certification. 
B.  Specific Requirements. The plasmapheresis procedure shall meet the following minimum requirements: 
1.  Each donor shall be certified to be in good health and no person under the influence of alcohol or drugs shall be accepted as a donor. 
2.  A hematocrit determination shall be made immediately prior to each plasmapheresis procedure. Plasmapheresis shall not be performed if the donor has a hematocrit less than forty for males and thirty-eight for females. 
3.  A total serum protein determination shall be made immediately prior to each plasmapheresis procedure. To be acceptable, the donor's total serum protein shall be not less than six grams per one hundred milliliters of serum. 
4.  A donor identification systems shall be established that positively identifies each donor and relates such donor to his blood and its components as well as to his accumulated records and laboratory data. Such system shall include either a photograph of each donor, which photograph shall be used on each visit to confirm the donor's identity, or some other method that provides equal or greater assurance of positively identifying the donor. 
5.  Physical status of the donor and accumulated laboratory data shall be reviewed by a licensed physician at least once every four months after the initial donation. Only those donors certified to be in good health upon such review shall remain in the plasmapheresis program. 
6.  The system used for the collection of blood and the separation of the plasma shall meet the approval of the Director of Health and shall provide for positive identification of all containers. The system shall also result in a sterile final product, without contamination of the red blood cells, which shall be returned to the donor. This shall be done with normal accepted procedure. 
7.  The ratio of blood collected to anticoagulant solution in the container shall be that specified for the appropriate anticoagulant. 
8.  The amount of whole blood removed from a donor during any plasmapheresis procedure, or within any forty-eight-hour period, shall not exceed one thousand milliliters from a person less than one hundred seventy-five pounds and shall not exceed one thousand two hundred milliliters from a person over one hundred seventy-five pounds. 
9.  The amount of whole blood removed from a donor within any seven-day period shall not exceed two thousand milliliters from a person less than one hundred seventy-five pounds and shall not exceed two thousand four hundred milliliters from a person over one hundred seventy-five pounds. 
10.  The plasma shall be separated from the red blood cells immediately after blood collection and the red blood cells shall be returned immediately to the donor after each such separation. 
11.  A registered nurse or physician shall be in attendance at all times when donors are undergoing plasmapheresis. The registered nurse or physician shall be responsible for supervision and maintenance of sterile technique. The nurse shall refer to a physician any person who appears to be under the influence of alcohol or other drugs or not in good health, prior to accepting the individual as a donor. 
12.  Handwashing facilities shall be present both in the room where donors are bled and in the room where blood cells are separated from plasma. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 523-1973) 
111.374 - Immunization of donors. 
    If specific immunization of a donor is to be performed, the immunization schedule for each donor shall be under the supervision of a licensed physician who shall be responsible for the selection and administration of the antigen involved and for the evaluation of the donor response. Any antigen administered shall be a product described in the application for certification and approved for use in humans by the Federal Food and Drug Administration. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 523-1973) 
111.375 - Laboratory tests. 
A.  Serological Test for Syphilis. Blood used to prepare source plasma (human) shall be nonreactive for a test for syphilis. All donors with reactive tests for syphilis shall be reported immediately to the Department of Public Health. 
B.  Test for Hepatitis Associated Antigen. All blood to prepare source plasma (human) shall be tested for hepatitis associated antigen by a technique approved by both the Federal Food and Drug Administration and the Director of Health. Names of all plasma donors who are hepatitis associated antigen (HAA) positive shall be reported weekly to the Department. All donors with a history of hepatitis, HAA positivity, or reactions during plasmapheresis shall be permanently disqualified from future donations. The covers of charts of rejected donors shall be clearly marked with the date and the reason for rejection. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 523-1973) 
111.376 - Processing. 
    All surfaces that come in contact with plasma or blood shall be both sterile and pyrogen-free. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 523-1973) 
111.377 - Records. 
    Records shall be maintained for all plasma donations including the name, age, and address of donors, the dates of each donation, the antigen or antigens administered, and all laboratory tests performed. Such records shall be made available to the Director of Health on request. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 523-1973) 
Article 23. - Police and Fire Emergency Alarms 

111.378 - Title-Purpose-Scope. 
A.  Title. This article shall be known as Police and Fire Emergency Alarms. 
B.  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to protect the police and fire emergency services of this City from misuse, and to encourage alarm users and alarm businesses to maintain the operational reliability and the property use of alarm systems in limiting unnecessary police and fire emergency responses. 
C.  Scope. This article governs and regulates alarm systems, alarm users, and alarm businesses, and establishes fees, provides for revocation of licenses, and provides for the punishment of violations. 
(Ord. 344-1991; Ord. 983-1979) 
111.379 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "Alarm administrator." A person or persons appointed by the Mayor to administer, control, and review alarm applications, licenses, and false alarm notifications. 
    "Alarm box." A device whose purpose is to send a coded telegraphic message over the City's alarm circuit network to the Fire Department Communications Center for the purpose of alerting the Fire Department. 
    "Alarm business." The business by any individual, partnership, corporation, or other entity selling, leasing, maintaining, servicing, repairing, altering, replacing, moving, or installing any alarm system or causing to be sold, leased, maintained, serviced, repaired, altered, replaced, moved, or installed any alarm system in or on any building, structure, or facility. Contractors licensed by the City of Akron Division of Building Inspection for making electrical installations, and registered with the Ohio State Fire Marshal's office for making alarm installations, are exempt from the license fees under this article. 
    "Alarm business license year." A twelve-month period beginning with the first of January and ending on the last day of December of each year. 
    "Alarm notification." A notification intended to summon the police or fire service, which is designed to either be initiated purposely by a person or by an alarm system that responds to a stimulus characteristic of unauthorized intrusion or the products of combustion which include but are not limited to heat, smoke, and light radiation. 
    "Alarm Review Board." A board that consists of one representative from the Police Department, Fire Department, and the professional alarm industry as well as two members from the public at large, all appointed by the Mayor, with the approval of City Council. 
    "Alarm site." A single premise or location served by an alarm system or systems. 
    "Alarm system." A device or system that emits, transmits, or relays a signal intended to summon, or that would reasonably be expected to summon, police or fire service of the City, included but not limited to local alarms. Alarm system does not include: 
1.  An alarm installed on a vehicle unless the vehicle is permanently located at site; nor 
2.  An alarm designed to alert only inhabitants of a premise that does not have a local alarm. 
    "Alarm user." A person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind in control of any building, structure, or facility where an alarm system is maintained. 
    "Alarm user license period." A twelve-month period beginning with the date of issuance, except licenses for alarm sites classified as owner-occupied residential units shall be for a thirty-six month period beginning with the date of issuance. 
    "Automatic dialing device." A device which is interconnected to a telephone line and is programmed to select a predetermined telephone number and transmit by a voice message or code signal an emergency message indicating the need for an emergency response. 
    "False alarm notification." The activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, or the negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or of his employees or agents. Such terminology does not include, for example, alarms caused by hurricanes, tornadoes, earthquakes, or other similarly violent conditions. 
    "Interconnect." To connect an alarm system including an automatic dialing device to a telephone line, either directly or through a mechanical device that utilizes the telephone, for the purpose of using the telephone line to transmit a message upon the activation of the alarm system. 
    "License section." The section of the Treasury Division of the Finance Department of the City authorized to issue licenses and collect the fees for same as provided herein. 
    "Local alarms." Alarms which activate an audible signal within the proximity of the premises only. 
    "License holder." The person designated in the application as required in  111.381(C)(1) who is responsible for responding to alarms and giving access to the site, and who is responsible for proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees. 
    "Person." An individual, corporation, partnership, association, organization, or similar entity. 
    "Primary trunkline." A telephone line leading directly into the Police or Fire Department which is for the purpose of handling emergency calls on a person-to-person basis, and which is identified by a specific number in the telephone directory. 
    "Special trunkline." A telephone line leading into the Police or Fire Department and having the primary purpose of handling emergency signals or messages originating either directly or through a central location from automatic dialing devices. 
(Ord. 884-1992; Ord. 182-1992; Ord. 344-1991; Ord. 983-1979) 
111.380 - Alarm business license. 
A.  An individual, partnership, corporation, or other entity engaging in an alarm business within the City shall apply to the Licensing Section for a license to operate. The application shall be on a form to be furnished by the Licensing Section and signed by the individual proprietor of such business, or by a partner, or by the proper corporate official as is appropriate for the form of the business seeking the license, and shall include: 
1.  The name, address, and telephone number of the alarm business and the type of business entity (e.g., individual, partnership, or corporate). The name, address, and telephone number of the individual proprietor, partners, or directors and principal officers, depending on the nature of the entity applying. A licensed alarm business shall notify the Alarm Administrator of any changes that would alter any information listed on the license application within two business days. No fee will be assessed for such changes; 
2.  A description of the alarm systems and devices offered for sale or lease to the public and a description of any services related to alarm devices offered to the public; 
3.  Certification that within ninety days after the effective date of this article or upon receipt of notice of approval of a license application, whichever date occurs later, a complete list of the names and addresses of all persons or businesses in the City to whom or for whom alarm systems have been sold and who are currently under contract to the alarm business; 
4.  A list of all felony and misdemeanor convictions of individual proprietors, partners, or directors and principal officers of the applicant business. The date and location of each conviction shall also be included; 
5.  A statement as to whether the applicant has been denied a license or permit in any jurisdiction to engage in the alarm business or has had such license or permit revoked; 
6.  A statement as to the length of time the applicant has been engaged in the alarm business and where engaged. 
B.  License applications shall be accompanied by a certificate of insurance in a minimum amount required by the State Fire Marshal. 
C.  License applications shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable annual fee of one hundred fifty dollars to cover the costs to the City of processing the applications as described herein. 
D.  Alarm businesses already engaged in providing services or alarm system equipment in the City on the effective date of this article shall submit an application for a license no later than sixty days after the effective date of this article. After 1991, an application for a license shall be submitted no later than January 1 of each subsequent year. The applicant may continue to do business while their license applications are being processed. An applicant not previously engaged in providing services as an alarm business in the City on the effective date of this article shall not commence doing business until his application is approved. 
E.  Every alarm business shall meet the experience requirement of this article before it may engage in the alarm business. 
1.  At least one individual who is an owner, officer, partner, or employee of the applicant shall establish that he was engaged in or employed by an alarm business, in sales, service, or installation for an aggregate period of two years prior to filing this application. Such individual shall file with the Alarm Administrator sworn statements of such experience by at least two citizens of the community or communities in which such individual was so engaged or employed. The individual whom the applicant relies upon to comply with this subsection shall be a person who devotes a substantial portion of his time to engaging in or supervising the sale, installation, or servicing of alarm systems on behalf of the applicant. 
2.  For the purpose of the two-year experience requirement of subsection (E)(1) of this section, employment by or engagement in an alarm business in one or more communities within the state may be aggregated. 
3.  In the event that the individual upon whom the applicant relies upon to comply with subsection (E)(1) of this section shall within a period of three years after such compliance or qualification, for any reason cease to perform his duties on a regular basis, the alarm business shall promptly notify the Alarm Administrator by certified or registered mail and shall obtain as promptly as possible a substitute eligible individual acceptable to the Alarm Administrator. If the alarm business fails to obtain such substitute eligible individual within six months from and after the disqualification of such individual, the Alarm Administrator may revoke the alarm business license or may in its discretion extend for a reasonable time the period for obtaining a substitute qualified individual; or said Alarm Administrator may determine, based upon experience and performance of the alarm business, that the alarm business need not obtain such substitute qualifying individual. 
F.  The Alarm Administrator shall review each application for a license prior to the licensing section issuing an alarm business license and may conduct an investigation to determine whether the facts set forth in the application are true. He shall within sixty days after receipt of an application for such license either approve or deny issuance of same and, accordingly, forward written notification to the applicant of said decision by certified mail. A written notification of denial shall include the basis for said finding and if the grounds for denial are subject to correction, applicant shall be given ten days after receipt of such notice within which to make the required correction. 
G.  The Alarm Administrator may deny the application for an alarm business license if he finds that the applicant or the individual having the authority and the responsibility for the management and operation of the applicant's alarm business within the City or the individual upon whom the applicant relies to comply with subsection (E)(1) of this section, or any of the applicants, owners, partners, or principal corporate officers have: 
1.  Committed any act which if committed by a licensee would be grounds for revocation of a license under subsection H of this section; or 
2.  While unlicensed knowingly and willfully committed or aided and abetted in the commission of any act for which a license is required by this article; or 
3.  Been convicted in any jurisdiction of a felony or misdemeanor if the Alarm Administrator finds that such conviction reflects unfavorably on the fitness of the applicant to engage in the alarm business. 
H.  A new alarm business shall provide the Alarm Administrator with a written list of all alarm users prior to the licensing section issuing an alarm business license. 
I.  Licenses for alarm businesses may not be renewed in the manner hereinafter set forth if the licensee or any of its owners, partners, principal corporate officers, or the individual having the authority and the responsibility for the management and operation of the alarm business within the City are: 
1.  Found to have violated any of the provisions of this article; or any rule or regulation of the Alarm Administrator which violation the Alarm Administrator determines to reflect unfavorably upon the fitness of the licensee to engage in the alarm business; or 
2.  Found to have knowingly and willfully given any false information of a material nature in connection with an application for a license or a renewal or reinstatement of a license or in a notice of transfer of an alarm business licensed under this article; or 
3.  Found to have been convicted in any jurisdiction of a felony or a misdemeanor if the Alarm Administrator determines that such conviction reflects unfavorably on the fitness of the applicant to engage in the alarm business; or 
4.  Found to have committed any act while the license was not in effect which would be cause for the revocation of a license, or grounds for the denial of an application for a license; or 
5.  Upon petition to the Alarm Administrator by a local governmental subdivision, found to have been convicted of a violation of a municipal ordinance which violation the Alarm Administrator determines to reflect unfavorably upon the fitness of the licensee to engage in the alarm business. 
J.  An alarm business shall provide the Alarm Administrator with a written list of all alarm users annually prior to renewal of a license and shall make its records available to the Alarm Administrator or his designee upon request. 
K.  No license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be assigned or transferred either by operation of law or otherwise. 
L.  No alarm business shall operate within the City of Akron without a license. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 884-1992; Ord. 344-1991; Ord. 983-1979 
111.381 - Alarm users license. 
A.  No alarm user shall operate or cause to be operated an alarm system without a license. A separate license is required for each alarm system at each alarm site. 
B.  The application shall be on a form to be furnished by the licensing section. Completed application forms shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable annual license fee of twenty-five dollars for a new license and fifteen dollars for a license renewal. The Alarm Administrator shall review all applications for licenses prior to the Licensing Section issuing a license and shall approve the issuance of a license unless the applicant has: 
1.  Had an alarm license for the alarm site revoked, and the violation has not been corrected. 
C.  Each license applicant must include the following information: 
1.  The name, address, and telephone number of the person who will be the license holder and be responsible for the proper maintenance and operation of the alarm system and payment of fees assessed under this article; 
2.  The classification of the alarm site (e.g. single-family residential, apartment, commercial, financial, or government); 
3.  For each alarm system located at the alarm site, the purpose of the alarm system (e.g., burglary, robbery, panic, or the products of combustion which include but are not limited to heat, smoke, and light radiation); 
4.  The date of installation, the date of the most recent maintenance inspection and the person or company responsible for maintaining the alarm system; 
5.  Other information required by the Alarm Administrator necessary for the enforcement of this article. 
D.  Any false statement of a material matter made by an applicant for the purpose of obtaining a license shall be sufficient cause for refusal to issue a license or to revoke a license. 
E.  An alarm license cannot be transferred to another alarm user. A license holder shall inform the Alarm Administrator, who will then notify the Licensing Section, of any change that alters any information listed on the license application within two business days of the change. No fee will be assessed for such changes. 
F.  All fees and assessments owed by an applicant must be paid before a license may be issued or renewed. 
G.  Upon review and approval by the Alarm Administrator, the Licensing Section shall issue the alarm license. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 182-1992; Ord. 344-1991; Ord. 217-1981; Ord. 92-1981; Ord. 171-1980; Ord. 983-1979) 
111.382 - Alarm monitoring fee. 
    Those alarm users whose alarm systems are connected directly to the Police or Fire Department Communications Center or to any Fire Department alarm box shall pay an annual monitoring fee of seven hundred fifty dollars for each alarm system monitored and shall be subject to all of the same rules and regulations of this article with regard to licensing and false alarms. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 344-1991; Ord. 983-1979) 
111.383 - Proper alarm operation and maintenance. 
A.  A license holder shall: 
1.  Maintain the premises and the alarm system in a manner that will minimize or eliminate false alarm notifications; and 
2.  Respond or cause a representative to appear at the systems location within a reasonable period of time not to exceed thirty minutes, when notified by the City to provide access to the premises, or to provide security for the premises; and 
3.  Respond or cause a representative to appear at the systems location within a reasonable period of time, when notified by the City to deactivate a malfunctioning alarm system; 
4.  Not manually activate an alarm for any reason other than an occurrence of an event that the alarm system was intended to report. 
B.  A license holder or his representative of a local police alarm shall adjust the mechanism or cause the mechanism to be adjusted so that an audible alarm signal will sound for no longer than ten minutes after being activated. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 344-1991; Ord. 983-1979) 
111.384 - Installation and/or maintenance of alarm systems. 
    A license holder of an alarm system shall not contract or retain an alarm business who is not properly licensed by the City of Akron. 
(Ord. 344-1991) 
111.385 - Indirect alarm reporting. 
A.  An alarm business shall: 
1.  Report alarms only over trunklines or other communication facilities designated by the Alarm Administrator; and 
2.  Communicate alarm notifications to the City in a manner and form determined by the Alarm Administrator. 
(Ord. 344-1991) 
111.386 - Alarm system operating instructions. 
    A license holder shall maintain at each alarm site a complete set of written operating instructions for each alarm system. Special codes, combinations, or passwords shall not be included in these instructions. 
(Ord. 344-1991) 
111.387 - Alarm dispatch records. 
A.  An officer responding to an alarm notification shall record such information as necessary to permit the Alarm Administrator to maintain records, including but not limited to, the following information: 
1.  Identification of the license holder if known; 
2.  Address of the alarm site; 
3.  Date and time; 
4.  Weather conditions; 
5.  Area of premises involved; 
6.  Name of license holder's representative on premises, if any; and 
7.  Cause of alarm (e.g., criminal offense, weather, false alarm, heat, smoke, or fire). 
(Ord. 344-1991) 
111.388 - System performance reviews. 
    If there is reason to believe that an alarm system is not being used or maintained in a manner that insures proper operation and suppresses false alarms, the Alarm Administrator may require a conference with a license holder and/or alarm business responsible for maintenance of the alarm system to review the circumstances of each false alarm. 
(Ord. 344-1991) 
111.389 - False alarm notifications. 
A.  A license holder may be subject to warning, fees, or revocation of an alarm license depending on the number of false alarm notifications emitted from an alarm system within one year of the date of issuance of license, or in the case of owner-occupied residential units, within one year of the date of issuance of the license or within one year of the first or second anniversary of the date of issuance of the license based upon the following schedule: 
Number of False Alarm Notifications Action Taken 3 Warning Letter 4-7 An administrative fee of fifty dollars for each 8-9 An administrative fee of two hundred fifty dollars for each 10 or more Revocation of license and an administrative fee of five hundred dollars for each  
B.  Notice of any action taken pursuant to subsection 111.389(A) shall be personally served or sent by certified mail to the license holder's last known address. If the certified mail notice is returned unclaimed or refused, notice shall be sent by regular U.S. mail. Payment of any fee assessed under subsection 111.389(A) must be paid within ten days of the last notice sent. 
(Ord. 884-1992; Ord. 344-1991) 
111.390 - Revocation of alarm license. 
A.  The Alarm Administrator shall revoke an alarm license if it is determined that: 
1.  There is a false statement of a material matter in the application for a license; or 
2.  The license holder has violated  111.383, 111.384, 111.385, 111.386, or 111.389; or 
3.  Ten or more false alarm notifications have been emitted from the alarm site as provided in  111.389. 
B.  No person shall operate or cause to be operated an alarm system during the period in which his alarm license is revoked. 
(Ord. 884-1992; Ord. 344-1991) 
111.391 - Appeal from denial or revocation of a license. 
A.  If the Alarm Administrator denies the issuance or renewal of any license or revokes any license under this article, he shall send written notice of his action and a statement of the right to an appeal, by certified mail, to both the applicant or license holder and the applicable alarm installing/service company. 
1.  The applicant or license holder may appeal the decision of the Alarm Administrator to the Alarm Review Board, by filing a written request, on a form provided by the Alarm Administrator, for review setting forth the reasons for the appeal within ten days, after receipt of the notice from the Alarm Administrator. 
2.  Filing a request for appeal shall stay the action by the Alarm Administrator of revoking a license until the Alarm Review Board has completed its review. If a request for appeal is not made within the ten-day period the action of the Alarm Administrator is final. 
B.  The Alarm Review Board must schedule a hearing within ten days after the request for an appeal hearing has been requested. The Alarm Review Board will conduct a formal hearing and consider the evidence by any interested person(s). The Board shall make its decision on the basis of a preponderance of the evidence presented at the hearing. The Board must render a decision within seven days after the hearing. The Board may affirm, reverse, or modify the action of the Alarm Administrator. The decision of the Board is final as to administrative remedies within the city. 
(Ord. 344-1991) 
111.392 - Reinstatement of a license. 
A.  A person whose alarm license has been revoked may be issued a new license if the person: 
1.  Submits an updated application and pays the applicable fee and any outstanding fees assessed under this article; and 
2.  Pays, or otherwise resolves, all citations in court issued to him under this article; and 
3.  Corrects all reasons for revocation of the license to the Alarm Administrator's satisfaction. 
(Ord. 344-1991) 
111.393 - Interpretation. 
    This article shall be liberally construed to effect the purpose of the sections included herein and to achieve uniform interpretation and application of the respective sections. 
(Ord. 344-1991; Ord. 983-1979) 
111.394 - Records. 
    The Police Department, Fire Department and the Licensing Section of the Finance Department shall not release any records maintained pursuant to this article without first obtaining the approval of the Law Department. 
(Ord. 543-1991) 
111.395 - Penalty. 
    Whoever violates or fails to comply with  111.380(L), 111.381(A), or 111.390(B) of this article is guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree and shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars or imprisoned not more than sixty days, or both. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. 543-1991; Ord. 344-1991) 
Article 24. - Private Investigators and Agencies 

111.400 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "Business as a private investigation agency." The conducting, for hire, in person or through a partner or employees, of any investigation relevant to any crime or wrong done or threatened, or to obtain information on the identity, habits, conduct, movements, whereabouts, affiliations, transactions, reputation, credibility, or character of any person, or to locate and recover lost or stolen property, or to determine the cause of or responsibility for any libel or slander, or any fire, accident, or damage to property, or to secure evidence for use in any legislative, administrative, or judicial investigation or proceeding. 
    "Business of security services." Either of the following: 
1.  Furnishing, for hire, watchmen, guards, private patrolmen, or other persons whose primary duties are to protect persons or property; 
2.  Furnishing, for hire, guard dogs, or armored motor vehicle security services, in connection with the protection of person or property. 
    "Department of Commerce." The division of licensing established within the Department of Commerce under R.C.  121.07 to administer the provisions of R.C. Chapter 4749. 
    "Private investigator." Any person conducting business as a private investigation agency. 
    "Report quarterly." Written reports received no later than: January 15; April 15; July 15; and October 15 of every year. These quarterly reports due on the fifteenth shall include information current as of January 1; April 1; July 1; and October 1 of every year. 
    "Security guard provider." Any person who engages in the business of security services. 
    "State of Ohio license" or "Ohio agency license." Any one of the following: 
1.  A Class A license issued under R.C.  4749.03 that qualifies the person issued the license to engage in the business of private investigation and the business of security services; 
2.  A Class B license issued under R.C.  4749.03 that qualifies the person issued the license to engage only in the business of private investigation; 
3.  A Class C license issued under R.C.  4749.03 that qualifies the person issued the license to engage only in the business of security services. 
    "Transfer." Any lease, sale, or other disposition of at least twenty-five percent of the assets or control of the agency or business. 
    "Written notice." Notification in writing mailed, telegraphed, or delivered to the address of the person for whom such notification is intended. If mailed, such notification shall be by first class mail. 
(Ord. 441-1986) 
111.401 - Registration of private investigation agencies and security guard providers. 
    No person, firm, or corporation required to be licensed by the State of Ohio, Department of Commerce, shall conduct business as a private investigation agency or security guard provider within the corporate limits of the City unless: 
A.  The person, firm, or corporation has first been licensed by the State of Ohio as required by R.C. Chapter 4749; and 
B.  The person, firm, or corporation has furnished the Police Division with a copy of their current State of Ohio agency license and registers on forms provided by the Police Division. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 441-1986) 
111.402 - Employees of agencies to be registered with the State of Ohio. 
    No state licensed agency shall permit an employee who is required to be registered with the State of Ohio, Department of Commerce, to work within the corporation limits of the City until such employee has been processed by the Department of Commerce and has been issued a registration card by that Department except that pending the issuance of a registration card, a licensee may offer for hire security guard or investigator employees provided the licensee obtains a signed written waiver from the person who receives, for hire, security guard or investigative services, acknowledging that the person is aware the employees have not completed their State of Ohio registration and agreeing to their employment. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 441-1986) 
111.403 - Identification required on person during hours of employment. 
A.  Any licensee, registered employee of a licensed agency, or person working under a signed waiver for a licensed agency, shall have on their person during the hours of employment or duty, within the city, their State of Ohio license, registration card, or copy of signed waiver, which shall be subject at all times to inspection by any member of the Police Division. 
B.  Any private investigator or security guard provider, whenever engaged in the licensee's business, shall produce their State of Ohio license, registration card, or waiver upon request by any citizen. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 441-1986, passed 6-30-86) 
111.404 - Reports required. 
    All agencies registered with the Police Division are required to complete and submit a report quarterly, or as requested by the Chief of Police, on forms provided by the Police Division, listing current agency information and registered employee information. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 441-1986) 
111.405 - Radio use. 
    No person, firm, or corporation shall use any official radio frequency assigned to the Police Division by the Federal Communication Commission for the purpose of communicating with any other person, firm, or corporation, without the express written approval of the Chief of Police. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 441-1986) 
111.406 - Transfer of agency or business. 
A.  Any person, firm, or corporation licensed to conduct business as a security guard provider or a private investigation agency within the City shall provide written notice of any transfer of the business or agency to the Chief of the Police Division and any person, firm, or corporation who receives the security guard or investigative services within ten days of the date of transfer. 
B.  Written notice shall include, but not be limited to, the following information: the date of the transfer; the name and address of the transferor; and the name and address of the transferee. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 441-1986) 
Article 25. - Rendering Establishments 

111.440 - Regulations for reduction of animal matter. 
    No person shall conduct the business of operating any process, apparatus, or other device for the purpose of reducing animal matter to tankage or fertilizer or of rendering greases from animal matter, except in compliance with the following provisions: 
A.  A closed system of operation shall be used throughout the process of rendering or reduction. 
B.  No less than two water-jet condensers or other adequate apparatus approved by the Department of Public Health shall be installed and connected in a proper manner with all digesting tanks and at no time shall any digesting tank be operated without using the condenser aforesaid in a proper manner. 
C.  The discharge from the condensing apparatus required in subsection B of this section shall be connected with the City sanitary sewerage system. In the discharge line, before the same enters the City sanitary sewerage system, a device known as a hotwell or other suitable apparatus to be approved by the Director of Health shall be installed, into which hotwell or other apparatus gases which are insoluble in water shall be discharged, to be treated by connecting such hotwell with an apparatus for deodorizing such insoluble gases before allowing the same to escape in the open air. Such apparatus and process must be maintained and operated in a manner satisfactory to the Director. 
D.  Water once used for condensing obnoxious gases shall not be permitted again to circulate or be otherwise used. 
E.  Water pressure at all times during the operation of such condensers shall be maintained at not less than fifty pounds, and in the operation of the digesting tanks, a steam pressure in the relief line from digesting tanks to the condenser shall not exceed forty pounds at any time while the same are in use. In order to insure compliance with this provision, pressure gauges shall be installed by the operator of such business whenever and wherever required by the Department. 
F.  A self-recording temperature thermometer shall be installed in the discharge line for each and every water-jet condenser. Such installation shall be between the condenser and the hotwell or approved substitute apparatus required by subsection C of this section. The thermometer shall be accurate and accurate records of temperatures recorded thereby shall be made on a daily chart which shall be correctly dated. All records of such self-recording temperature thermometer shall be available at all times for the inspection of the representatives of the Department and such records or exact copies thereof shall be furnished such inspectors for use of the Director. 
G.  In the operation of the aforesaid process, a temperature shall not be permitted to arise in the discharge line from the condensing apparatus in excess of one hundred forty degrees Fahrenheit at any time. 
H.  All water drawn from wet tankage shall be passed immediately into a sanitary sewer, after removing all grease therefrom, and no such water shall be evaporated or permitted to evaporate in open tanks. Penalty, see  111.999. 
111.441 - Steamtight vessels required. 
    No person shall melt or render in the City any fat or grease unless such fat or grease is free from sourness or taint and unless such melting and rendering is done and conducted in a steamtight vessel which is so constructed and maintained as to allow no vapor to escape therefrom while any part of the contents of such vessel has a temperature of more than one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit and unless the unutilized gases and vapors therefrom are so treated as not to become a public nuisance, and unless the premises where such melting or rendering is conducted, and all utensils, implements, and receptacles used in connection with such melting and rendering, are kept clean at all tines. Penalty, see  111.999. 
111.442 - Dead animals-Keeping unsalted or uncured hides. 
A.  No dead animal brought into the City shall be rendered within the limits of the city. 
B.  No person shall keep for more than twenty-four hours any unsalted or uncured hides. Penalty, see  111.999. 
111.443 - Disposal of offensive substances. 
    No person owning or having the possession, charge, or management of any building or premises used in whole or in part as a storehouse, market house, tannery, tallow chandlery, slaughterhouse, meat packing establishment, rendering establishment, soap boiling establishment, bone crushing establishment, or place for the manufacture, storage, treatment, or handling of fertilizer, chemicals, glue, tar, dead animals, hides, bone, shell, blood, scrap, fat, grease, or other animal or vegetable matter, or in which building or on which premises any other traffic, industry, or operation is conducted, shall permit the accumulation in, or the discharge or removal from, such building or premises of any substance that is foul, putrid, offensive, dangerous, or detrimental to public health, other than in tightly covered containers, so constructed and maintained as to permit no part of the contents to spill, leak, or evaporate therefrom. Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the outflow of sewage into a public sewer. Penalty, see  111.999. 
111.444 - Cleanliness of buildings, materials, and receptacles. 
    No person owning or having possession, charge, or management of any building or premises used in whole or in part as a storehouse, market house, tannery, tallow chandlery, slaughterhouse, meat packing establishment, rendering establishment, bone crushing establishment, soap boiling establishment, or place for the manufacture, storage, treatment or handling of fertilizer, chemicals, glue, tar, dead animals, hides, bones, shell, blood, scrap, fat, grease, or other animal or vegetable matter, or in which building or on which premises any other traffic, industry, or operation is conducted, shall permit such building or premises or any part thereof or any utensil or implement, receptacle, or substance contained therein or thereon to become foul, nauseous, offensive, or in any way a nuisance or detrimental to the public health. Penalty, see  111.999. 
Article 26. - Residential Social Services Facilities 

111.450 - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    "Residential social service facility." A home or facility operated by persons other than the residents themselves, in which three or more persons reside while receiving treatment or services designed to help them adjust to the community and society. The term does not include the residence of related individuals, nursing or rest homes, child-care centers as described in  111.140 through 111.143, or independent living in which residents themselves operate the facility. The term includes but is not limited to facilities commonly known as three-quarter-way homes, halfway houses, transitional residences, group homes, runaway or temporary shelters, and veterans' homes. 
1.  A "family residential social service facility." A residential social service facility in which three to five, but not more than five, individuals reside. 
2.  A "group residential social service facility." A residential social service facility in which more than five individuals reside. 
(Ord. 574-1979) 
111.451 - License required. 
    No person shall operate a residential social service facility or knowingly permit the operation thereof without first procuring a license therefor. No license shall be issued for a new residential social service facility that will be located within a two thousand foot radius of another residential social service facility already in lawful operation. Those residential social service facilities that are in lawful operation on the effective date of this article may be issued a license notwithstanding the two thousand foot limit, provided they are in compliance with all the other sections of this article. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 574-1979) 
111.452 - License requirements. 
A.  The Director of Public Health shall issue licenses to those, and only those, operators of proposed family residential social service facilities who submit the following: 
1.  The written approval of the Chief of Fire Prevention, issued after inspection for compliance with the Fire Prevention Code applicable to the facility. 
2.  The written approval of the Superintendent of the Department of Building Inspection, issued after inspection for compliance with the building code. 
3.  The written approval of the Director of Health or his deputy, issued after inspection for compliance with the environmental health housing code. 
4.  A letter of intent to provide the Police Department with current emergency contact information. 
5.  An agreement or contract with the community health center responsible for outpatient case management in the catchment area designated by the Summit County Mental Health and Mental Retardation Board (648 Board), if the family residential social service facility is for mental health. 
6.  An application form containing the following: 
a.  The name, address, and telephone number of: 
1.  The owner of the property on which the family residential social service facility is located. 
2.  The operator of the family residential social service facility. 
b.  The number of individuals to reside in the facility, the general nature of their needs, and the assistance to be provided them. 
c.  The name by which the family residential social service facility shall operate. 
d.  A typewritten copy of the rules of the family residential social service facility, along with a statement of the level of supervision that is to be provided, and the rules for the storing and taking of medication. Each resident of the family residential social service facility shall also be provided with a copy of such rules. 
e.  A statement of admission procedures and policy. 
7.  Such additional information as the Director of Public Health or the Superintendent of Building Inspection deems necessary to preserve the health, safety, and welfare of the family residential social service facility residents and public, consistent with the provisions of this article, providing such information does not infringe upon the residents' rights of personal privacy. 
8.  Payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars for each new license or twenty-five dollars for each renewal of a license. 
B.  The Director of Public Health shall issue licenses to those, and only those, operators of proposed group residential social service facilities who submit the following: 
1.  A license, or evidence that one is forthcoming from the appropriate governmental body. A group residential social service facility operating as a home for the mentally ill or the mentally retarded must be licensed by the Ohio Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation. 
2.  The written approval of the Chief of Fire Prevention, issued after inspection for compliance with the fire prevention code applicable to the facility. 
3.  A certificate of occupancy as required by  153.110, issued by the Superintendent of the Department of Building Inspection; except that, a group residential social service facility established under R.C.  5123.l8 shall be required only to be inspected and approved for compliance with the building and fire prevention codes. 
4.  A certificate of compliance with the environmental health housing code, issued by the Director of Health. 
5.  A letter of intent to provide the Police Department with current emergency contact information. 
6.  An application form containing the following: 
a.  The names, address, and telephone number of: 
1.  The owner of the property on which the group residential social service facility is located. 
2.  The operator of the group residential social service facility. 
b.  The number of individuals to reside in the facility, the general nature of their needs, and the assistance to be provided them. 
c.  The name by which the group residential social service facility shall operate. 
d.  A typewritten copy of the rules of the group residential social service facility, along with a statement of the level of supervision that is to be provided, and the rules for the storing and taking of medication. Each resident of the group residential social service facility shall also be provided a copy of the rules. 
e.  A statement of admission procedures and policy. 
7.  Such additional information as the Director of Public Health or the Superintendent of Building Inspection deems necessary to preserve the health, safety, and welfare of the group residential social service facility residents and public, consistent with the provisions of this article, providing such information does not infringe upon the residents' rights of personal privacy: 
8.  Payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars for each new license or twenty-five dollars for each renewal of a license. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 574-1979) 
111.453 - Renewal of licenses. 
    All licenses shall be issued for a period of one year. Prior to the expiration of the one-year term, the residential social service facility shall be inspected by the Director of Public Health or his appointed agent. Upon the satisfaction of the Director of Public Health that such facility is in compliance with all provisions of this article, the Director of Public Health shall renew said facility's license for a period of one year. Except that those residential social service facilities operating under a license from the Ohio Department of Mental Health and Mental Retardation shall renew their licenses concurrently with the state license. Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 574-1979) 
111.454 - Information referral. 
    The Department of Public Health shall send the information required to be submitted by  111.452 to the police, fire, and zoning officials of the city. The Director of Public Health shall consult these officials in determining what information is to be included on the application, as expressed in 111.452(A)(7) and (B)(7). Penalty, see  111.999. 
(Ord. 574-1979) 
111.455 - License revocation. 
    The license of a residential social service facility may be revoked by the Director of Public Health if such facility violates the minimum standards set forth in this article. 
(Ord. 574-1979) 
Article 27. - Roller Skating Rinks 

111.460 - License. 
A.  Requirement. No person shall own or operate a hall, room, rink, or ground used for roller skating by the public without first obtaining a license therefor as provided in this article. 
B.  Fee-Term-Transfer. 
1.  The license fee, payable to the License Clerk at the time of application, shall be one hundred eighty-five dollars for each business location. This fee which is paid at the time of application is not refundable in any case. Upon approval of the application by the Mayor, the License Clerk shall issue a license for a period of one year from the date thereof.
